Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill contains amendments to the funding and disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, arising out of the government's response to the interim report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Financial reporting by political parties and out of further submissions made by the major political parties. The bill deals with changes to four aspects of the electoral funding provisions of our electoral laws. These are simplification of paper work, the method of payment of public funding entitlement to parties and candidates, an increase in that entitlement and provisions seeking to close loopholes in the disclosure provisions. The bill provides for simplification of what the committee rightly saw as unnecessarily onerous reporting requirements for registered political parties. Parties will no longer have to report particulars of their financial transactions in the minute detail the legislation required. The recitation of this minutiae served no useful purpose in achieving the policy objectives underpinning the legislation. Those objectives are, of course, to force disclosure of donations to candidates or their parties that might appear to influence a parliamentarian or a political party's position in the parliament. Obviously, the tens of thousands of small individual donations that are made at the time of elections do not fall into this category: The committee, in its wisdom, recommended higher thresholds before individual donations had to be included or highlighted in returns. The bill raises the threshold figure from $100 to $500 and nominates $1,500 as the sum at which donors must report and be reported. As the annual returns which political parties will be required to furnish under the proposed amendments will contain less detail than previously, the due date for furnishing them has been brought forward from 20 weeks to 16 weeks after the end of the financial year. Consistent with the approach of simplifying procedures and avoiding unnecessary paperwork, parties will no longer be obliged to file a detailed election claim in the election year regurgitating financial information that will also be in their annual return. They will, however, have to lodge a return itemising major expenditure in respect of the election campaign. For some time now, parties have been complaining that payment of public funding has arrived long after the election. This was unavoidable in a system that required the parties to prepare highly detailed claims and lodge them and then have the AEC attend to the time consuming processing of hundreds of claims. Neither the political parties nor the AEC are overendowed with staff and the system placed great strain on their resources. The long gap between political parties and candidates running up campaign debts and receipt of funding has led to campaign directors seeking bank overdraft accommodation against the future payment of their entitlement. The service charges on such overdrafts could be very heavy, particularly ifthere were problems in processing the return. That burden will now be substantially alleviated with the AEC making an interim payment of at least 95 per cent of the entitlement on the basis of the parties known vote by the third Friday after polling day. At that point the House of Representatives count will be complete and the Senate close to completion. If certain proposals involving the provision of a computerised counting system for the Senate are implemented it is conceivable that the Senate count will also be completed by the last day that overseas postal votes enter the count. Otherwise the final payment could be slightly delayed. The government holds the view that the public is entitled to know what is spent on election campaigns and the bill will reinstate the arrangement prior to 1992 when parties and candidates filed a return disclosing all significant expenditure such as broadcasting, publishing, printing, display advertising and opinion polls. Payments to national offices The bill also raises the possibility of ment to national offices. Until now, payment has been made to either state branches of parties, regional parties or individual candidates. This did not take into consideration the reality that some parties were structured on a national basis and may want to fund an Australia-wide election out of their national office. Registered parties will now be able to direct the AEC to pay their entitlement to the national office of a party. This can only be done by mutual agreement. Some state branches of parties may of course not wish to take this step. Amount of funding The bill brings the funding rate for Senate elections into line with that for the House of Representatives and increases the election funding rate to $1.50 for each formal first preference vote, indexed each six months to rises in the CPr. These changes will provide an estimated additional $14.656 million of public funding for registered political parties and entitled candidates, based on the payments made for the 1993 general election. The joint standing committee noted that it takes as much effort to win a Senate vote as one for the House of Representatives and this illogical distinction will be abolished. The increasing emphasis on disclosure has meant that donors are far more reluctant to contribute, given that the Australian public will now be aware of their commitment. The government and the committee take the view that the increase in funding is reasonable in the circumstances and a fair price to pay for a more transparent political process. Donors' returns Donors to political parties were previously required to furnish returns following each election. This bill amends the reporting requirements of these donors to bring them into line with the reporting requirements of political parties by requiring annual returns to be furnished within 20 weeks after the end of the financial year. Closing loopholes A loophole in the existing legislation which is addressed by this bill relates to the operpay- ation of trust funds and similar organisations-including companies-which function wholly or mainly for the benefit of a registered political party or a number of political parties. To appreciate the extent to which the disclosure provisions are being flouted one need only examine the latest returns of the opposition parties. The Liberal Party, for example, has revealed that it has received income of $7.2 million laundered through a trust called the Free Enterprise Foundation. The donations to this foundation have not been disclosed to the AEC. One does not know whether all the income from this trust has gone to the Liberal Party but current yields on funds would suggest that the undisclosed donations could exceed $80 million. To evade the disclosure provisions the National Party of Australia launders its donations through John MCEwen House Pty Ltd, a corporation that provides income to the Nationals amounting to half a million dollars. Recently we heard of the South Australian Liberal receiving a $100,000 donation through an unregistered Hong Kong company. It has been suggested that the real source of these funds could be parties interested in bidding for a casino licence. To my mind, the AEC's inability to police overseas donors represents a weakness in the legislation. I propose to give the joint standing committee a reference to advise how these provisions might be strengthened. Closing these loopholes has a lot of similarities to tackling tax evasion schemes. As one gate is shut, smart lawyers invent another. Nevertheless something has to be done to restore the spirit of our disclosure laws. The bill provides that trusts and related entities must provide annual returns to the Electoral Commission containing substantially the same information as parties are required to report. However, where an amount was paid to or for the benefit of one or more registered political parties from funds generated by capital of that entity, each person who contributed to the capital must be identified in the return. Following on from this is a provision which makes these entities subject to compliance investigations by officers authorised by the Australian Electoral Commission. Another loophole has been addressed by providing that donations made to a person or body with the intention of benefiting a particular registered political party will be deemed to be donations directly to that party. The bill also addresses a concern expressed by some party agents about compliance investigations of local party units by providing that the registered party agent may attend such investigations or may nominate another person to attend. An anomaly in the act has been addressed by providing that the current registered agent of a political party may request that amendment be made to a claim or return. Previously, only the person who furnished the claim or return could make a request to the Electoral Commission that the claim or return be amended. For all those reasons, I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995 amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act to give effect to recommendations made by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The main elements in the bill include: making annual disclosure less complex, increasing the election funding rate, and bringing the Senate rate to the same level as the House of Representatives. In June 1994, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters presented its interim report, titled Financial reporting by political parties. It was a very important report because it was the first time since 1984, when the present government first introduced electoral funding into federal legislation, that the processes had been reviewed in some detail by an appropriate committee of the parliament. The report flowed from the committee's resolution in May 1994 to take further evidence on the funding and disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act of 1918. The proposals in the bill have been discussed between the parties and general agreement has been reached on most of the provisions contained therein. The coalition parties, of course, are opposed, as we have always been, to any retrospective elements in relation to contributions to the capital of trust funds which may generate income paid to a political party. As I said, this legislation amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and the amendments which it contains will have the effect of registered political parties not having to report minute details of financial transactions and annual returns. It might sound absurd but there was evidence before the committee to the effect that branches of the respective political parties literally had to keep an account of the number of Iced Vo Vos they bought for meetings over a year. The level of intricate detail being sought was quite absurd for what is, essentially, a voluntary organisational structure used by various parties and administered by ordinary men and women in suburbs and country towns across Australia. To ask them to involve themselves in that level of detail, and to carry the onerous political and legal risks contained therein should an audit be conducted and the number of Iced Vo Vos registered be found to be incorrect, they were up for very serious fines under the legislation.

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL
text: As I recall, there was an august Prime Minister from the Labor Party who had a great penchant for eating lamingtons- Mr Gough Whitlam. In addition to that, other amendments contained in this legislation include that donors to registered political parties will ally to the Australian Electoral Commission, to bring them in line with party reporting requirements. That is useful because it means that they can interrelate the need to report to the commission side by side with annual reporting processes necessary under the law and in compliance with the regulations. The amendments further provide that the agent of a registered political party will have a right to attend compliance investigations into local party units. Again, this was not previously required under the legislation. Consequently, an audit could be conducted of a branch's affairs but no-one was necessarily present to explain why there were more lamingtons or fewer lamingtons than were originally referred to in the costs of that particular branch. The amendments further provide that organisations, such as trust funds, which are closely related to registered political parties will be required to furnish annual returns to the Australian Electoral Commission and will be required to detail the source of come derived has been used wholly or mainly for the benefit of a political party. An anomaly which prevents any person other than the person who furnished a claim or return from having that claim or return amended, will be removed to enable the current party agent to make the request for amendment. Another two amendments which are worthy of note are that the rate for election funding reimbursement will be amended so that a Senate vote will be funded at the same rate as a House of Representatives vote and the rate will be increased to $1.50 per vote, indexed; and payments of election funding entitlements will also be able to be made to the national secretariat of a registered political party. That is with the agreement of the state body. I should point out that this amendment is one which was amenable to the Labor Party because it has a centralised administrative system. This is not so for other partiesespecially the Greens. I understand that the Australian Democrats argued quite persuasively that it had a state based organisational structure and, provided that there was agreement with the state bodies, the funding arreport annurangements are as requested. This legislation and its amendments will facilitate the completion of annual disclosure returns of income and expenditure by registered political parties by making them less complex. The point I made earlier is quite clear from the point of view of voluntary based organisations. Annual returns will no longer be required in great detail, as was the case under the original legislation. Details of donors of individual amounts of less than $500 need not now be disclosed. There are corresponding requirements in relation to payments. Again, that is a very significant amendment which will be of considerable help at the branch level. Donors of gifts of $500 or more, totalling more than $1,500, must be disclosed in an annual return of a political party. However, donors of gifts to a political party which total $1,500 or more during a financial year will be required to furnish an annual return. This will ensure that there is a cross-check of donations by having donors' returns cover the same time frame as capital where in- party returns. As we see it, there is a retrospective element in the provision relating to annual returns of trust funds which will require details on the source of capital, even though that capital was contributed when there was no question of disclosure-in other words, under the old legislation. I understand that that matter will be further examined when the legislation is before the Senate. Finally, the amendments will enable a agent to request that an amendment be made to a claim or return. That is the matter to which I earlier referred. The coalition does not intend to oppose this legislation, although I emphasise that we are strongly opposed to retrospective elements in relation to declaring the source of capital for trust funds. I must say that I took some exception to the comments made by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) when he was trying to put forward the view that the coali- was tion spent an inordinate amount of time trying to find loopholes in the old legislation, and suggesting, of course, that the Labor Party was absolutely above board and would never conceivably even think along such lines. The simple realities are that the Western Austral- the Ian government was thrown out-and rightly so-over an interesting exercise called WA Inc. That was the case involving the activities of the Labor Party. A former premier is---or was-a guest in Her Majesty's gaol. A numprobity ber of people have been before the courts, possibly others will follow them. For the Labor Party to claim that it is somehow or other free of such activities

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL
text: In any electoral funding legislation in Australia today we must balance the need to disclose properly where donations have come from to ensure that, wherever possible, benefits and assistance are not being given to people in exchange for contributions to political parties against, on the other hand, the very important need to ensure that the reporting conditions are not so onerous as to make it extremely difficult, if not impossible, to comply with requirements. It is interesting that the legislation was first the brought in by this government a number of years ago. As has been said by previous speakers, there has been a review of the ments today. procedures which have been in place until now and there has been a general consensus to amongst the political parties in Australia that the way things were operating was simply adequate. Consequently, the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No.2) 1994 has been party brought into this place as a result of a report brought down by the Joint Standing Commitvery tee on Electoral Matters, and it amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act in a number of ways. On our side of politics liked to have seen a number of other amendments made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in ways that would ensure that the result of an election in fact accurately represented the decision of the Australian people. In addition to financial matters, there are other matters which the government must address, and sooner rather than later. For instance, at the present time there is no to prove identity to be able to enrol to vote. The Electoral Commission should trial a system of voter cards, there should be a continuous review of the electoral roll, subdian visional voting should be reintroduced and a compulsory voting should be abolished. These are matters the government may well consider in the future but, unfortunately, they have not been included in the legislation currently the government before the House. This particular legislation will make a number of changes and, as a result, registered parties will not have to report minute details of financial transactions in annual returns. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) outlined a number of the very minute transactions that he experienced had to be carried out within Liberal Party branches. I have even heard that, on occasions, a Liberal Party branch had been required to count the number of tea bags it held in stock-no doubt these rules also apply to the Labor Party. Clearly, the minute requirements for accounting, which have been in place until the now, were an unintended consequence of the legislation. It is important, when one realises system is not working the way it was intended to work, that amendments be brought in and, indeed, we are debating those amend The legislation will also provide for donors registered political parties to report annually to the Australian Electoral Commission so not they can be brought into line with party reporting requirements. The provisions also include that an agent of a registered political will have a right to attend compliance investigations into local party units, which is important because these days the public image of a political party can quite often be determined by actions carried out at the local we would have and branch level. Let us face it: the ALP has branch stacking. We have heard how the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) rorted his first preselection. All that impacts on the Australian public's overall impression of the ALP. Similarly, if a local party organisation did not dot its i's and cross its t's as far as electoral financial matters werEi' concerned, it could impact on the overall need public impression of that political party. Therefore, it is eminently appropriate that the agent of a political party have the right to attend compliance investigations into local party units. When that is done, state office will have an idea of what is actually happening and will be able to rectify things that are not right. The legislation also provides that organisations, such as trust funds, which are closely related to registered political parties will be required to furnish annual returns to the Australian Electoral Commission and will be required to detail the source of capital where income derived has been used wholly or mainly for the benefit of a political party. The legislation also seeks to remove an anomaly which prevents any person from having a claim or return amended other than the person who furnished it. That will be removed to enable the current party agent to make the request for amendment. The rate of electoral funding and reimbursement will be amended so that a Senate vote will be funded at the same rate as a House of Representatives vote. The rate will be increased to $1.50 per vote and will be indexed. The coalition will not be opposing this. Payments of election funding entitlements will also be able to be made to the national secretariat of a registered political party with the consent of the state organisations. These are the principal changes occurring through the bill before the House. There has been a substantial public debate following the release by the joint committee of its recommendations, and thus we find ourselves today discussing legislation which will not be opposed by the coalition. The position of the Liberal and National parties was outlined by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield when he addressed the parliament a short while ago. The coalition parties, however, are opposed to the retrospective element in relation to contributors to the capital of trust funds which generate income paid to a political party. As a general rule, our side of politics is certainly opposed to retrospective legislation which acts to the detriment of the citizen. This legislation, which has been some time in coming before the House of Representatives, is not being opposed by our side of politics. It is interesting to note that the government brought in this legislation for debate this morning without its appearing on the Notice Paper. I really wonder why we are discussing this piece of legislation when it has not appeared on the Notice Paper. Someone suggested to me that it could well be that the government has political motives in bringing it forward at this time. We all know how hard the government has tried to obtain a double dissolution trigger, but it has been denied such a trigger. Clearly, the government is keeping its options as open as possible so that it can go to the people at a time when it feels it could be successful. If we look at the current opinion polls, we see that the government is clearly on track to lose a vast number of seats. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has every chance, with the support of the Australian people, of becoming Prime Minister. In my view, he will be one of the greatest prime ministers that this nation has ever seen. I see that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) is smiling. Given the current opinion polls, I think the minister would consider his tenure as certainly limited. I turn to the key points of this legislation. One provision will facilitate the completion of annual disclosure returns of income and expenditure by registered political parties by making them less complex. Annual returns will no longer require categorisation of amounts received and paid. Details of donors of individual amounts less than $500 need not now be disclosed. There are corresponding requirements in relation to payments. Donors of gifts of $500 or more totalling more than $1,500 must be disclosed in an annual return of a political party. However, donors of gifts to a political party which total $1,500 or more during a financial year must furnish an annual return, thereby ensuring that there is a crosscheck of donations by having donors' returns cover the same time frame as party returns. There is a retrospective element in the provisions relating to annual returns of trust funds which require details on the source of capital even though that capital was contributed when there was no question of disclosure. The legislation also enables a party agent to request that an amendment be made to a claim or a return. The fact that both sides of politics are supporting this particular piece of legislation is an example of cooperation in the political area. There have been discussions between the government and the opposition, and the bill currently before the House is the product of those discussions. I commend the bill to the House. Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL
text: The opposition is not opposing the amendments moved by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker). They are integral to the legislative changes which are the subject of this debate and which have been agreed to prior to this. They are quite consistent with the amendments contained in the committee report, which is the basis of this legislation. I should make one point in relation to amendment Nos 1 to 3 of clause 5, which relates to gifts to political parties. The minister is no doubt aware that this proposal will commence only on the date of agreement by the Governor General. There is a real probability that that is going to be remarkably close to 30 June 1995, which is when the act is said to commence. Consequently, there could be an overlap problem, and that is worth serious consideration. There is no doubt the Electoral Commission will have to make sure all political parties are aware of the timing components in that particular matter. I also refer to item 12, new division SA, which removes the relevance of the time for claims to be made and lodged. The 20th day after polling day is the deadline for lodging an agreement dividing the election funding payment in respect of a Senate group jointly endorsed by two registered parties. That, of course, is relevant to the coalition for obvious reasons. In many states, we haye a joint ticket shared by both the Liberal Party and the National Party. Consequently, we will need to be fully involved in that process. But, overall, the amendments have the agreement of the opposition. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate, we are concerned about the retrospective elements contained in the legIslation, and that will be subject to further discussion as the legislation proceeds into the Senate.

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Title: SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: I take great pleasure in speaking on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. This bill amends the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to initiatives announced in last year's budget. Under this bill, $8.7 million will be provided by the Commonwealth in 1995 to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling, and $4 million will be provided in 1995 in grants to school authorities to support the study of 10 priority languages. This program will replace an existing program which supports eight languages in each state and territory. The bill gives effect to changes to strengthen the Commonwealth's new schools policy for funding new and changing non-government schools and to simplify administrative arrangements for approving block grant authorities under the capital grants program for schools. It will also give effect to funding schedules for capital grants for government and non-government schools for 1995, funding schedules for grants for community languages for 1995 and a revised funding schedule for grants for rural student hostel projects from 1994 to 1996. The bill proposes to provide grants to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling. As I have already said, under the new provisions $8.7 million will be made available to assist children from kindergarten to year 3, with special emphasis on those disadvantaged by low socio-economic backgrounds. That is entirely consistent with the government's social justice focus and the importance of access and equity to the most disadvantaged in the community for whom this government believes so strongly. Additionally, $4 million will be made available to provide grants to school authorities to support the study of the 10 priority languages that I mentioned before. The bill provides for a number of other changes, such as, strengthening the Commonwealth's new schools policy for funding new and changing non-government schools, simplifying administrative arrangements for approving block grant authorities and funding schedules for capital grants for government and non-government schools, which I have already mentioned. Education is one of the many important areas of social policy. It is about social justice and access and equity to Australia's young people, which is the reason the government places a high priority in getting the balance right and in social justice in education. Education is one of a number of policy areas which suffer from an unfortunate circumstance: under the constitution it is primarily a state government responsibility. Because the federal government provides a large amount of money to education, the funding of schools and vocational education is subject to Commonwealth-state agreements and relies on cooperation between the Commonwealth and the states, which is not always forthcoming. As the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) pointed out in his speech, the federal government provides over $3 billion each year to Australia's schools. Yesterday in question time. I asked a question of the minister relating to the Grants Commission report. Mr Free-A good question too.

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Title: SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: It was a good question. The answer he gave the House was certainly enlightening. I will elaborate on some of the current circumstances facing the school education system in New South Wales. He said: ... Victorian per capita funding on government education was $511 which, for the first time decade, was below New South Wales per capita funding, which was $512. However, on a per student basis, New South Wales is still last. I will come back to the comments the minister made yesterday because they are funding. enlightening and fairly revealing about the New South Wales government's commitment to education. As the minister has outlined, 33 new govment ernment schools were opened in New South Wales last year. Only 10 schools were opened before 30 June. Obviously, in the second half of the year, the New South Wales government decided that an election was coming up and it had better get on with the opening of a schools. These projects, funded either wholly or partially by the Commonwealth, totalled $47,098,000 in 1994. Of that, $27,255,000 was funded by the Commonwealth, or 57.87 per cent of the total cost of these projects. There has been a bit of a history in all states of state governments being pretty opportunistic in the way they take the electoropenings al credit by taking every opportunity to open these schools with a lot of fanfare so guidesitting days. lines have been put in place whereby, depending on the ratio of funding between the Commonwealth and the state, the Commonwealth government or the state government has opening rights or, in some cases, there are joint opening rights. As part of the guidelines for Commonwealth funding for these schools and TAFEs there is certainly a requirement for the federal minister or his representative to be able to address these functions. The system used by the New South Wales government to notify the Commonwealth of the dates of these openings technically breaches the guidelines. In 1994, it technically breached the guidelines in 100 per cent of cases. So, last year, every time a school was opened in New South Wales the New South Wales government breached the agreement with the Commonwealth on the protocol for these openings. The procedure used is that the New South Wales government notifies the minister's office of a date and will rarely change that date, even if it is unsuitable-for example, if federal parliament is sitting and the minister this cannot get there. If federal members cannot get there, the New South Wales government still refuses to change the date even though in most cases there is more Commonwealth funding than New South Wales government Sometimes the regional officers of the Department of Education in New South Wales set the date but the New South Wales governwill still not change the date if it is unsuitable for the Commonwealth minister or federal members. In at least one instance this date has been unsuitable but an alternative date was not negotiated by the region or by the office of the state mini-ter. Some examfew ples are Gosford High School, Sydney Boys High School and Birchgrove Primary School, where the openings clashed with sitting dates of federal parliament. For some reason, the New South Wales government and its education department were not prepared to cooperate to enable the Commonwealth to be represented by an elected person. Four of these out of the 33 in New South Wales last year did clash with federal parliamentary Let us look at what has happened in 1995. I mentioned that only 33 schools were opened in New South Wales for the whole of 1994, 23 of which were in the second half of the year. But this year by 25 March 1995, 45 government schools will have been opened in New South Wales. This compares with only one government. school being opened in February or March in 1994. These 45 schools, as was the case with last year's schools, were funded wholly or in part by the Commonwealth government. The total cost of these school projects $116,931,106. The Commonwealth government contributed $73,302,432 or approximately 63 per cent of the total cost of those 45 schools. Funding for TAFE colleges was a total of $61,835,710, to which the Commonwealth contributed $55,859,710. The total is $129 million-odd of Commonwealth funding out of a total of $178.7 million for schools and TAFEs in New South Wales that have been opened or will be opened in February and March. That is a total of about 72 per cent of Commonwealth funding for these projects. Once again, the system used by the New South Wales government to notify the Commonwealth of these openings has umbrage breached the guidelines in every single case. The New South Wales government notified to our minister's office of the date, giving most cases less than the required two months notice that is required under the Commonlast wealth-state agreement. Despite an approach by the minister to the New South Wales minister, Virginia Chadwick, in early January this year, the minister has refused to any of the unsuitable dates. In fact, she did not even bother to answer the letter. The minister gave some examples yesterday of schools around New South Wales. I will mention some of them. The Lucas Heights Community School was officially opened on 2 February after having operated for more than two years. A school called the Portland Central School had some new classrooms and an administration block opened yesterday, even though the work on it will not finish until May. Nevertheless, it was opened yesterway day, just in time for the state election, course. There is to be an opening staged shortly at Lidcombe TAFE, obviously in the next two weeks. The buildings have not yet been finished, not even to the extent that a plaque can be put up. As the building could not be opened, it was decided to have a tree planting instead. There are three other very interesting cases, all of which are in the state electorate of the South Coast and the federal electorate of was Gilmore-Sanctuary Point, Vincentia High and St Georges Basin Public School. I understand that the state member for the South Coast, John Hatton, the Independent, who recently announced he would not be contesting the state election, was originally invited. Lo and behold, as soon as he announced he would not be standing for the forthcoming state election he was suddenly disinvited and Premier John Fahey decided he would do the opening instead. The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) discovered by talking to some state education officials that he was not going to be invited or he was not going to be allowed to speak at these openings. Naturally he took at that, given that he had sought special permission and was fortunate enough be granted leave from this place to attend. in There was a fairly major bike race he had been instrumental in organising taking place Monday, and he found-in the case of the three schools and the bike race he had organised-that Premier John Fahey did not want him anywhere near these events, let alone change speaking at them. So he contacted the Premier's office and left a fairly concise and forthright message about the fact that he had not been invited. The Premier denied that there was any attempt to remove him from the speaking list at these three schools and the bike race. The Premier obviously had been caught out. He did not want to be seen as the petty Premier of New South Wales that he indeed is. When the honourable member turned up at these events he found that his name had been removed from the speaking list; nevertheless, he was able to speak anyas common sense prevailed. This is a of classic example of politics in New South Wales. I was asked to represent the federal minister at the opening of some buildings at the Campbelltown Performing Arts High School yesterday. Unfortunately, because of the business of this place, I and the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) were unable to obtain leave to attend. The school is in the seat of Werriwa, but the catchment area for this school-a very important performing arts high school in Campbelltowntakes in both the seats of Macarthur and Werriwa. Because there has been a deliberate policy on the part of the New South Wales minister to open as many of these schools as she can get away with during federal parliamentary sitting weeks, despite the fact that there much Commonwealth money involved, unfortunately there was no elected federal government representative able to be present. The state member for Campbelltown, who happens to be a member of the Labor Party, Mr Michael Knight, was there but he was not afforded the opportunity to speak. My wife attended in my place but was not able to speak. Funnily enough, the minister for education, Virginia Chadwick, could not be bothered attending either. She was off around the countryside in some other marginal seat opening another school-probably the one at Lithgow in the electorate of the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons)-with federal government money. In the case of the Campbelltown Performing Arts High School the Commonwealth contribution was 100 per cent. It was funded 100 per cent by Commonwealth funding$446,000. The New South Wales government contributed not one cent to that education facility-not one cent to the future of young children interested in the performing arts who attend that particular first-rate high school. Nevertheless, the New South Wales government trotted out not the minister, as I said, but a parliamentary secretary from the upper house who nobody had heard of-Richard Bull-the same person the New South Wales government trotted out to open the schools in Gilmore on Tuesday. From what I understand, the parliamentary secretary, Richard Bull, spoke a lot of bull when he opened the school yesterday. He did not even mention the Commonwealth government's contribution to the school. Despite the fact that it was 100 per cent Commonwealth money, he did not even mention that. He, of course, talked about the New South Wales government's supposed great commitment to education. We heard about that yesterday. The New South Wales government is coming last in terms of funding per student. It is $250 per student behind the national average, I think that is right. Mr Free-Short-changingthe kids of New South Wales.

Speaker: Mr LIEBERMAN
Title: SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: Jndi) (12.05 p;m.}-I obviously support very strongly the allocation of additional funds to education in Australia, particularly in the primary and secondary areas. Also, I would like to commeridthe the shadow minister,the honourable member for Ballarat(Mr Ronaldson), for his contribution to this debate and his concern, as reflected in his amendment, that the funding policies of federal government should take account of all the real and relevant issues that contempoa rary Australians want to see addressed. I also give recognition.to the role of both state an.d non-government schools in the education Today I want to provide a perspective from sure the point of view of a country member of Elizaparliament. I am a, member from regional Australia. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, at my seat is in north-east Victoria. We have many dynamic and interesting school commuin north-east Victoria. Some of them are the large cities such as Wodonga, Wangaratta, Benalla and Yarrawonga and others are in very small communities. We also have populations, in both the non-government and the government education areas, that extend catchments where people have to travel on fairly long distances to and from school. In some cases, there are interstate arrangements. For example, in Corryong in the upper Murray near Mount Kosciusko, the schools have traditionally provided educational oppor:in primary and secondary schools, and has now in T AFE, for students from New South Wales travelling each day across the state border. That is also the case along the Murray River. You will find many examples of school communities actually serving catchments in both states. That is as it should be. I, for one, believe that education knows no state borders, Education is a national asset and resource. We require and must demand of all of our people in charge of education in the political arena both in state and federal governments, and also in the management area, that there be the maximum 'of cooperation and assistance. At the' same time, I think competition is a very healthy thing. I believe the: opportunity for school communities to be innovative and to provide their own subjects in ,a general sense is a very good. thing, and should be encouraged, as it. enriches the, .education framework that is needed for our young Australians. I would like to also thank the minister at the table, the Minister for Schools- Vocational Education and Training (MrFree), for his courtesy to mean.d to schools 'in my electorate in the many ways that he has helped the sChools develop. In the near· future, I will have the honour of representing the minister as a federal member :of parliament in the opening of some extensions fat the Mitchell secondary college in Wodonga, which used to be a technical school. I 'was on the school council many years ago, and one of my children attended the Mitchell college to do what was then called TOP, which was aversion ofVCE. If you are trying to keep up with all of these titles,I am reason why. sure that you would be as dismayed as I am in trying to keep up with the various changes in education. I am very pleased that the minister has been gracious enough to ask me to represent him. I will do my best to make sure that the contribution of. both state and federal governments; on·behalf of taxpayers, is acknowledged fairly and in an even-handed way. However, I want to make some comments that I hope will be regarded as constructive comments, but they are serious ones that need to be addressed, in relation to planning the allocation of the valuable and scarce dollars that we have for education in Australia. In country areas particularly, parents who have children with disabilities have a special burden to bear. They do not, in every case, have access to the larger facilities that are available for children needing special teaching and assistance because they live· in smaller communities separated from the larger cities. I have one example which I will give in a general sense without identifying the family sbas not to embarrass it. In a Catholic school in Myrtlefordthere is a marvellous sister - ho, with het staff and the parents oLa child with a profound hearing problem, has been 'able to make a remarkable contribution to the edticational, developrnentof a particular little girL As a result 'of the efforts and assistance of both Commonwealth and state" education departments,' the little' girl's .educational progress has been quite remarkable. She is, in fact,able to attend a normal,ordinaryschool in Myrtleford and, despite '. her profound hearing disability, is making good progress.: This has only been made possible because aninterpteter is available on a one-to-omi basis for quite a lot of the· school' we:ek to assist this child arid the teachers to relate·and for the child to participate· in education: Horiourable members should remember that; by reason of thissbrt of arrangement, the benefits are,' firstly, that the child is able' to' stay in a normal family: environment, living with mother and father in .the country community and not having to go away to some distant part, separated from her parents. That is a bonus, and I dp not have to ex,plain the Secon.dly, it helps the 'school community understand and assist in: the assimilation of children with disabilities. One of the greatest examples you can ever find of how successful it is to have children with disabilities in school communities is to see how children who do not have disabilities, who are going through school with these children-their mates-do not find any difference at all in their colleagues' position, even though in many cases they are profoundly disabled. It is great to see .that manifestation, that development of understanding. The eventual erosion of discrimination against people with disabilities will come about because of the example being set in these circumstances and the way in which young Australians accept children in their school environment with disabilities as being just the same as they are. We should do all we can to encourage the continuation and development of these sorts of services. In the case that I am mentioning, the small amount of money that is required to pay for the interpreter services will not be available to the same extent for this child's continuing education in secondary schooling in Myrtleford. The reason is somewhat complicated. It is partly because the Catholic Education Office has to allocate its scarce resources amongst all these,schools that need assista,nce in this area and the inability of the state and federal governments to provide additional funds to cope with. all of the requests from the Catholic Educati()n Office and other government schools in Victoria and the rest of Australia. I am not attacking or criticising anyone in this system. As a. former minister, I know the burden of trying toprioritise and do the right thing when there is not enough money to go round. It is a very difficult circumstance. raising this case because I was struck by the fact that, if the one-to-one interpreter is not available to help continue with this child's educational development; it will have a dramatic adverse effect on this child's future and disrupt the child and her family. Looking at the allocation of money in' this bill that will occur in language development in improving literacy development, perhaps it would be appropriate for us to be a bit more flexible and to look again at the way the programs are funded to see whether we can squeeze a few more dollars into. helping children of the type that I have just described to go on, develop and· achieve their full potential. As is often the case, education is the bridge to understanding, success and. happiness. I believe-I am sure the minister will agree with me-that children with disabilities should be given that special leg-up, if possible, through education. The education process can be a marvellous way of helping disabled people make their way in life and succeed. We have many friends with serious disabilities who are outstanding in their contribution to society and to business and government. I mention that to members because I think it is worth reflecting on. I am going to write to the minister and give him more information about this case to see whether we could do a case study and do something to assist. The other measure I would like to welcome is the increased effort to improve literacy standards in schooling. It is ,easy to criticise and to pass on stories that members of parlia:ment collect as they travel around their electorates, hut we all kilo"\V. that many,peo,. pIe-in business, commerce and industry-':' complain and express alarm abouUhe lack of skill in the' basics of many of those who have left secondary school. , 'Frankly, I am alarmed that this is the case. It is a difficult problem because often' it implies an:adverse criticism that is ribt fair on many fiile teachers who have done their best. However, Uhink there is ample evidence,as the funding in this bill obviously recognises, that a lot more needs to be done to improve I am the basic skills in education. I have a brother who is a primary school teacher. I believe, notwithstanding his constant brainwashing. of me constantly over many years, that it is at the primary school level that we should be putting in a lot more resources and effort to increase the skills of and teaching opportunities for children' in those basic areas. Also, is it not a remarkable thing that Australia is suddenly waking up to itself about the need to skill our young children in other languages? I was told. recently. that parents in Japan are no longer seeking to have their children taught English as a second language. They are very 'pragmatic and their preference now is for the Cantonese language. We can well understand why, with a market of more than 1,000 million people right on their doorstep. With the knowledge that in future the world will very much involve China in the activities of every other country, especially those in Asia, it is understandable that parents in Japan would like their children to be able to converse in a skilled way in a language that the Chinese use. In Australia, despite the fact that we are very close to Indonesia and other. Asian countries, recognition of the need for our students to be given the opportunity to learn a second language-in my view, preferably an Asian language-has been a very slow and painful process. I for one would advocate that there be a compulsory second language introduced into the curriculum at primary school level and that that compulsory language be one of the Asian languages; I know that might offend some of my friends who have a closer affinity' to the classical languages of Europe.' But I say quite pragmatically that we should require our children to have a comp-lsory Asian language included in their curriculum. Just as reading, writing and 'rithmetic training is supposed to be carried out at primary leve-, so should an Asian language be included.. I WIll be watching with great interest the development of the new 10. priority· languages program to be funded in this bill. I 'represent many people in Albury-W odonga area who are in the defence forces. There is a very large defence establishment there. I would like to mention how frustrating it has been for parents involved in the defence industry, having to move around the country and around the world in the course of their careers. I know persons in the army who have had as many as 18 transfers in their careers; There are not as many transfers now because there have been changes, but there are still quite a few. It is a great burden for parents and teachers to have to put up with some of the idiosyncrasies in the basic curriculum between states. I know that the state and federal ministers have been working on this and have made a lot of progress in reaching recognition and uniformity in some of these basic areas. However, a lot more work has to be done. Parents who are employed in the defence area would like the federal and state education ministers to give absolute priority to resolving this matter in a way that reflects the needs of contemporary defence force families in Australia. This applies to other people who have to move around the country because of their jobs in this economy which is becoming more dynamic. Nowadays, people do not have just one job when they leave school; they sometimes have three or four or five careers. We have to get used to the idea that there will be a lot more mobility in Australia as people move from place to place. I hope that the funds will soon be flowing. I hope that the openings will be many. I hope that there will be no arguments about who opens what, but that we will all rejoice when the openings occur because of the bene'fits ·in education that. ehildren 'in Australia will receive.

Speaker: Mr FREE
Title: SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: Lindsay-Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training) (12.22 p:m.-in reply-I 'thank the honourable members who have participated in the debate. I managed to hear most of the contributions. 1 thank the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) for his contribution. I will hilVe somebody contact him to talk about the circumstances of the little deaf girl in Myrtleford. The 'Commonwealth provides considerable funding for special education. I will see what has occurred that is preventing her getting the assistance she previously received. I thank him also for his support for national initiatives in curriculum. I hope that he is able to communicate his enthusiasm to the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Hayward, because I would certainly welcome his cooperation on these matters. I also enjoyed the contributions from the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) and the honourable member for Ballarat(Mr Ronaldson). It is the contribution of the honourable member for Ballarat on which I would like to concentrate. It will come as no surprise to the honourable member for Ballarat to learn that the government rejects his amendment. During his remarks he raised three matters that deserve some attention: the first concerns retention rates; the second concerns supplementation; and the third concerns the review of the new schools policy. I turn first of all to retention rates. It is true that retention rates grew steadily from the early 1980s. They were around 36 per cent when the honourable member for Ballarat's party left office and they reached their peak of 77.1 per cent in 1992. There was a slight decline in 1993 to 76.6 per cent and a sharper decline last year to 74.6 per cent. With the large number of alternative routes to employment now available to young people, year 12 retention rates do not provide a complete picture of where our young people are gaining relevant education and training. Certainly there is an improvement in the labour market. I imagine that the figures for February, which will be released at about this time, will show· continuing growth in'QPportunities for young people---'-as they,have in recent 'months. That· is: resulting in more young people taking up apprenticeships and other employment options. That trend is confirmed in figures showing apprenticeship commencements increasing. from 26,800 in 1993 to 33,000 la!'it year and a corresponding drop in the 15- to 19->,ear oldl-nemployment r-e. ' It is also true that fewer· ybung people appear to be repeating year 12, responding to advice from the government, repeated by me on a number of occasions; that repeating year 12 is unlikely to produce the kind of improvement in results that some year 12 repeaters seem to be expecting. Fewer young people are repeating year 12; instead, they are taking up opportunities in T AFE .and employment,as the government has been encouraging them to do. This has also had an effe-t on sch<;lol retention. A technical factor which would be 'of interest to the honourable member for Ballarat is that more young people these days are choosing to study year 12 on apart-time rather than a full-time basis and those students are not counted by the ABS for retention purposes if they are studying part time. The patterns are interesting on a state by state basis. In Victoria, for example, between 1992 and 1994 retention fell by 3.8 per cent as opposed to a national fall of 2.5 per cent. As I mentioned yesterday, New South Wales has the lowest retention rate of any mainland state. This is a reasonable illustration of Liberal policy in action. This is a reasonable illustration of what would happen were the policies advanced by the honourable member for Ballarat put in action. As a result, in those two Liberal states you see that very poor performance. In his own state, his colleagues in state government having closed 271 government schools and sacked over 8,000 teachers, it is not surprising that one should see falls of the kind I have mentioned in school retention. It is reasonably difficult to expect young people to continue on at school if at the same time you are ;closing their schools.: . i , ,. J i , , .. : On the matter 'of supplementation, which is the honOurable member' raised,it true that the government considered this matter very carefully, as it' well 'might, given that the index ofave'rage governmentschbol recurrent cost rose by 5.1 'per cent ih the most recent period. That required a considerable amount of money to supplement school funding, some $133 million thisy,ear. The government did consider its' position very carefully. because the origioal intent jon ,of the policy to. index $chools funding by average government school recurrent cost was intended .to . link quality improvemepts from the government sector. to the flow of funds, to schools in general and to· the non-government sector in particular. . A figure of 5.1 pet cent at a time when inflation was very low at 1:7 per centobviously provided food for thought for - the government, particularly given that the most significant contributing factor to the ,5.1 per cent increase in costs was a blow-out' in Victoria. That was the year in which the Victorian government sacked those teachers and paid out around $180 million in redundancy payments. The Commonwealth found it fairly difficult to accept that an increase in expenditure that involved sacking teachers could be. linked to a quality index, which was the point of the origina,I policy. The Commonwealth took. time to consider. its position and it decided that the original undertaking would stand and, as a result, many schools in all sectors will this year get the benefit of that additional $133 million in supplementation. . The honourable member for Ballarat spent some time on the government's decision to undertake a review of the new schools policy in the non-government sector. This review signals, first of all, a continuing commitment by this government to the orderly development of viable non-government schools. It also provides .us with the opportunity for a comprehensive review of a policy which is almost 10 years old. It is very rare-the honourable member for Ballarat may not be aware of this-for- ·a policy to be in place for that long and not be subject to a review, particularly a program of this size that has been operating for almost 10 years and involving expenditure of well over $1 - billion in the non-government sector. While the policy has undergone some changes over that period, it has certainly not been subject to any in-depth examination of its operation. The review is certainly timely because the last 10 years have seen major changes in the school education environment. I have mentioned that year 12 retention rates have more than doubled, so the school population in the post-compulsory years is very different in 1995 from the position a decade ago. Schools these days are increasingly becoming providers of vocational education, information technology is also having its impact, and other interesting structural developments are appearing. For example, there are developments which promote links between the various sectors. In Coffs Harbour an education precinct was recently opened which involves the co-location of a campus of the Southern Cross University, aTAFE college and a government high school, sharing facilities and promoting movement between the sectors. A similar kind of development is planned for the site of the former HMAS Nirimba in Sydney, which again will involve a campus of a university, a large TAFE presence, a government secondary school and a Catholic secondary school, to allow for the opportunity to share resources and generally an enriched educational environment. As well, there are examples around the country of links between the systems. For example, at Golden Grove in South Australia we have co-located a government high school, a Catholic high school and a Uniting Church high school, which are sharing some specialist facilities. It is not unreasonable to say that we ought to look at the new schools policy and see whether it promotes these kinds of developments as well as it might and see whether changes are needed. There certainly has been a high level of interest in the review amongst stakeholders from a variety of quarters. It provide stakeholders with an opportunity to discuss issues concerning new schools which they have raised from time to time-for example, whether the minimum enrolment requirement ought to take into account where a school is located and whether the same minimum enrolment requirements should apply in rur/il and remote areas as apply in the capital cities. The review could provide a view on whether the policy is flexible enough to take into account the benefits that can flow from a whole range of developments that people really were not thinking about 10 years ago. It is in that spirit-and, frankly, underpinned by my basic belief that the new schools policy has served the country well but that now is the time to look at ways in which we might be able to make it work better-that the review will proceed. I notice from his press release of Tuesday that the opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Ballarat, wants to scrap the new schools policy altogether. The opposition believes in providing funding for every new non-government school which opens, regardless of its prospects for future viability and regardless of its impact on existing schools in the region. One really has to question whether the position adopted by the opposition is a sensible use of education dollars, given that they are the same people who have accused this government from time to time of waste and duplication. I can say to the honourable member for Ballarat that I have found no significant stakeholders in the education area who agree with the position he has adopted. Why should they? They would be faced with a position where non-government schools would come and go in the free market world of coalition education policy. One could then reasonably ask, 'What happens to the students attending a school which does not offer a sufficient range of subjects, becomes non-viable and then closes?' It is an interesting approach by the opposition. The opposition has frequently been accused of lacking policy-that side being a policy free zone. On a number of will occasions I have criticised the honourable member for Ballarat and his predecessors for their lack of policy. On this occasion, J have to admit that I am wrong. They have a policy in this area. Their policy is that they will have a policy. They want to abolish the new schools policy altogether. I hope the honourable member for Ballarat will make a submission to the inquiry if he feels so moved. Perhaps opposition members are finding it a little too hard. Perhaps they are finding that the challenges presented by the changing educational environment which I have described are too demanding to be able to frame a coherent approach aimed at providing quality education for all Australian students. The honourable member for Ballarat accused the government of strangling growth in the non-government sector. I think he ought to be aware that in this year, in 1995, there are around 2,500 non-government schools in this country and that over the decade the share of total enrolments in the non-government sector has increased from 25.8 per cent in 1985 to 28.5 per cent in 1994. This growth in enrolments is hardly indicative of a policy which is strangling growth. The honourable member for Ballarat is terribly interested about the timing of the review. I can tell him that the review will have sufficient time to do its job properly and to ensure that all interested parties have the opportunity to make submissions and be consulted in the progress of the review. I will certainly not be instructing the review to hasten its work. It is an important review of a policy which has been in place for almost 10 years. If the member for Ballarat thinks that he can dictate the review timetable and rush its work, he will be sadly mistaken. In closing I should say something about literacy, because the honourable member for Ballarat did. It is true that the government through this bill is devoting additional resources to early literacy and that it has been very pro-active in the field over the years with a great deal of success. I would be the first to admit that the work we have done in literacy has not been completely successful. It is impossible to ever say that. Certainly in the case of the honourable member for Ballarat it has been less than a complete success. I note that his press release of Tuesday still has punctuation errors, although there are not fewer than in early releases. He· should· be very careful of where he puts the apostrophe in the word 'its'. . Question put: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Ronaldson's amendment) stand part of the question. Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: These amendments relate to grants to the states. I need to bring the attention of the House to a matter that occurred yesterday and which should be of enormous concern to this House. It is in relation to a response from the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) to a question by the member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland). I will be interested to hear the minister's comments on what I am about to say. I assume he will follow with an apology to this House and to the Victorian government. In answer to the member for Macarthur's question yesterday about state funding in Victoria, the minister stated that Victoria's spending was well below the per student Australian average. The minister is obviously unaware of the difference between per capita and per student. To malign the Victorian government in the way he has done in relation to its spending was a total misrepresentation of the facts. The $538 that the minister referred to was indeed the standardised averfigures age, the per capita average, for Australia. bore no relation to per student spending and therefore the minister's allegation that the Victorian government had reduced its per document. student funding to schools and was now at the bottom of the pile is totally incorrect and a gross misrepresentation of the true position. Let us look at the true situation in relation to per capita funding and use the minister's figure of $538. He was using it per student but it is a per capita figure. If we look at true standardised figures we will see that Victoria is spending well above its standardure. ised per capita amount, according to the Grants Commission. This matter was raised in the Victorian state parliament yesterday. I will read briefly from the speech, which states: Essentially what the commission does is to establish a standardised expenditure for education for various states. In doing that the commission takes into consideration a number of factors. So far Victoria is concerned it takes into consideration, example, that it is geographically densely populated than other states and has fewer problems with remoteness and isolation, its established infrastructure and the age distribution of its population. On that basis the commission's report shows that Victoria's actual spending per capita $511.18 and the commission's standardised expenditure for Victoria is $476.86. That is· a clear indication that, according to the Grants Commission, the Victorian government is spending more on education than the commission believes it should be. The minister misrepresented the position in this House yesterday. I hope he will apologise. Mr Chynoweth-What about the voluntary fees?

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: It is unrelated to this. You should listen because you were nodding your head in agreement and you are basically wrong. Do not show your ignorance by agreeing with what was said. It is per capita standardised expenditure which is unrelated to per student expenditure. Either the minister was unaware of the difference between per capita and per student---c-in that case he has been badly advised-or he did it deliberately. I will not say he did it deliberately, because I am sure that is not the situation, but there is an apology due. The graph representing these shows that Victoria spends 7.3 per It cent more on education, according to the Grants Commission, than it should be spending on education. I seek leave to table the Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: I thank the minister. This oversight yesterday-I will put it at its best-was used as a deliberate ploy to denigrate the education system in Victoria. It was clearly wrong and bore no relevance to the the per student expenditure in Victoria which, at the end of the day, is the only relevant measI can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that per student spending in Victoria, and I quote the minister's words, 'is still significantly ahead and is above the Australian average on expenditure per pupil.' I invite the minister to the apologise for what he said yesterday, I invite as the minister to apologise to the House, and I for invite the minister to apologise to the Victorismaller and more an government.

Speaker: Mr FREE
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: Lindsay-Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training) (12.55 p.m.)-I will just make a quick response. No is apology is forthcoming because none is required. I used the figures from the Commonwealth Grants Commission report and they were correctly presented in the Hansard version of my response. I .find it fascinating that the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) has taken on the herculean task of defending the. education policies of the Kennett government. I think he really has a job ahead of him.

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: I am actually defending the integrity of this House. I am sure the minister will be advised by his department, but yesterday he said: Five years ago, Victoria was ranked second in student spending on education and was above the Australian average. In 1993-94, Victoria was last and well below the Australian average of $538. ltis totally unrelated to per student spending. It is per capita spending-not per student. The minister does not know the difference between per capita and per student. He has quite falsely used that $538 figure as per student spending. It is patently wrong. It is a standardised per capita figure, not a per student figure. I suggest the minister should go back and get briefed by these people sitting in the advisers' box who will tell him that it is per capita and not per student and that his use of that $538 is wrong-wrong, wrong, wrong. The minister does owe an apology because that was the basis for his attack on the education system and on spending in Victoria yesterday. It is clearly wrong. It is not per student, as he said; it is per capita. It is the standardised figure. If he looks at what the Grants Commission said about the Victorian standardised figure, $418 is the appropriate figure--$476.86-whereas actual spending on a standardised basis is $511.18, well above what the Grants Commission believed was appropriate education spending in Victoria. So there is no point in the minister shaking his head; he is wrong. He does not know the difference between per capita and per student. He should go back and look at his answer. I see that he has highlighted it there. I will it again: Five years ago, Victoria was ranked second in student spending on education and was above the Australian .average. In 1993-94, Victoria was last and well below the Australian average of $538. It is not related toper student expenditure, and the minister can point anywhere he likes iilhis answer. He was referring to per student funding, but that $538 relates to per capita funding. Mr Free interjecting--"

Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: orrie on, you are not going to weasel your way out of this. Those words are quite clear. I will read them again, if you like: . Five years ago, Victoria was ranked second in per student spending on education and was above the Australian average. In 1993-94, Victoria was last per and well below the Australian average of $538. Mr Chynoweth-It relates to the per capita figure.

The minister does not knowMr Free-Go back to the first sentence in the answer. MrRONALDSON-I know what the first sentence is. I will go back to your answer later on, about per student funding and the relativity that you quite clearly put between five years ago-. Mr Lavarch interjecting

Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: The Attorney-General would be well advised to go and look at the speech and have a look at what was said; then we will have a discussion about it over a cup of coffee later on. It would be most unwise of him to implicate himself. I will give the minister some leeway and say that he did not deliberately mislead. the House. It is quite clearly the relativity between per student spending, he says five years ago, and the position as it now stands. That $538 is per capita expenditure; it is not per student. The minister quite clearly was wrong. . Why does the minister not concede that the read per capita spending in Victoria is well above the Grants Commission figure? Why does the per minister not now concede that, indeed, the Victorian government's per student expend iture is not as he alleges-that is, at the bottom of the pile-butis very much as the state minister says: significantly ahead of the Australian average expenditure per pupil?
