Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: in reply-This occasignificance sion marks the closure of the second reading debate on the First Corporate Law Simplificafinancial tion Bill 1994, and it follows the referral the bill to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on 8 February of this year. The government thanks the members of the committee for producing a priate report on the bill in such a timely fashion. Together with the committee, the government acknowledges the efforts of all those who provided submissions to the committee or appeared before it. The committee report deals with a number of concerns about specifed ic provisions which have been raised in the parliamentary debate on the bill or in submisand sions to the committee. I now table the government's response to the committee registers. report. In these brief remarks, I will just mention two of the main issues arising from the report: the distinction between small and large proprietary companies, and the question access to debenture registers. One of the reforms in the bill is to reduce the financial reporting requirements of small proprietary companies. The bill makes the distinction access between small and large companies for this purpose by using a three-part objective test which looks at assets, revenue and employees. The committee concluded that, on balance, it preferred the small and large test,as a basis for distinguishing· between proprietary companies, to the reporting entity concept advanced by the accounting bodies. The committee recommended that serious consideration be given to two options: namely, that the employees criteria remain, or that the employees test be deleted from the bill and the test for a small or large proprietary be on the proposed assets and turnover criteria alone. The current test in the bill is designed to achieve an approxirpate measure of the company's economic significance. It provides a measure of flexibility which enables the test to be targeted in a manner which seems to the government to be If the bill were to be amended to rely on two criteria alone, it would become a less test of a company's economic and, accordingly, a less appropriate touchstone for the application of corporate reporting requirements. Having said of that, I advise that the government has noted carefully the committee's comments on these criteria and will keep them under review. If the employees criteria proves to be inapproin practice, the government will certainly be prepared to re-examine the issue. The bill contains important new safeguards to protect the privacy of debenture holders and of other securities holders whose details are shown in registers. The committee provida full opportunity for both the representatives of the Australian Finance Conference members of the simplification task force to discuss the rules in the bill on debenture The committee has not proposed any change to the new protections included in the bill. However, it has recommended that an additional provision should be inserted to give the of ASC the same power of exemption as it key presently has. The government acknowledges that there are points to be made-both for and against-providing additional restrictions on to debenture registers, but it has decided to accept the committee's view that the ASC should be able to provide such restrictions as it might consider necessary. I thank all members who contributed to this debate. The debate was actually conducted some weeks ago in the House, and the matter was then referred to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities; The committee report was a useful addition to the debate. I thank everyone involved. The First Corporate Law Simplification Bill is important legislation. The government will be moving some amendments during the consideration in detail stage. . Question resolved in the affirmative .. Bill read a second time. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: by leave-I move: (1) Clause 2, page I, subclause (I), line 9, "and 2", substitute ", 2 and 7". (2) After clause 6, page 2, insert the following new clause: "7 Commencement of Schedule 6 to the Corposiders rations Legislation Amendment Act 1994 Section 2 of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1994 is amended by omitting subsection (2) and substituting the following subsection: '(2) Schedule 6 commences on the day which the First Corporate Law Simplification Act 1995 receives the Royal Assent.'.". (3) Schedule 4, page 68, item 84, omit "before 'Section 126"', substitute "after 'Section (4) Schedule 5, page 76, proposed section 216F, add at the end: "(6) ASC power in relation to register ofdebenture holders The ASC may exempt a company from complying with subsections (1) and (3) in relation ASC to information in a register of debenture holders about debentures that are not converdebenture tible into shares or options over unissued shares. "(7) The exemption: (a) must be in writing; and (b) may be general or limited; and (c) may be subject to conditions specified in the exemption. "(8) The ASC must publish a copy of the exemption in the Gazette. "(9) A person must not contravene a condition the exemption. "(10) On application by the ASC,.the Court may order a person who contravenes a condition of the exemption to comply with the condi 7 tion.". .. The first two proposed am-ndQ1ents c.oncern schedule 6 of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1994, which provides for the introduction of the concept·of penalty units into the Corporations Law. Due to unexpected delays in the passage of state legislation . concerning other unrelated matters in the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1994, it has not been possible to commence schedule 6 of that act. It is proposed to amend the commencement provisions of schedule 6 by amending subsection 2(2) of the Corporations Legislation Amendment Act 1994. Schedule 6 will now commence on the day on which the First omit Corporate Law Simplification Bill· receives royal assent. Because the bill contains a number of penalties which are expressed in terms of penalty units, the government conit necessary to amend the Corporations Amendment Legislation Act in this way. The. third proposed amendment to the bill arises because of a changed section reference in the law. The Corporations Legislation on Amendment Act 1994 has amended a section reference in the Corporations Law. For this reason, one of the references in the simplification bill is now incorrect. The third proposed lHAU"'. amendment will correct it. The final amendment implements the recommendation of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on registers of non-'convertible debentures. The will be enabled to exelJ1pt a company from the provisions in the bill on access to registers. Exemption will be able to apply only to non-convertible debentures. The exemption will have to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Any contravention of a condition of the exemption will be an offence. I also present the supplementary explanatory memorandum to those amendments. .

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: Berowra) (1.09 p.m.)As we are considering alI the amendments of together, let me say that, in relation to the work that was undertaken by the Joint Com(mittee on Corporations and Securities on the Corporate Law Simplification'Bill,the oppo:" sition believes that the: work that has been done ,and the amendments that have resulted demonstrate the virtue of having, the' opportunity to examine important bills of this character; Matters of very real concern were raised by a number of members on this side of the House who have spoken on'the bill. As I have said on a number of occasions, it is important to recognise that it is the Sen;:tte that has undoubtedly pioneered work in relation to deliberating on legislation. I think that there are more occasions on which the committees of the House ought to be used for such purposes. The government ought to facilitate and accommodate the reference of matters to committees of this House. It not only enhances the outcome but also ensures that there does not develop a view that the only people around this place who are able to add useful comments to and improve bills are senators. I think it is in interests of members of the. House of Representatives to be able to make those contributions. In this case, of course, it is the work of a joint committee, involving both senators and members of the House of Representatives. I think the value of it can be seen in the fact that the government has accepted a number of the amendments suggested by that committee, in addition to a number of its technical amendments. To go to the matter that we are discussing-the matter of the reporting entity test versus the test proposed in the bill-the distinction between small and large proprietary companies which will replace the current distinction between exempt and nonexempt companies was the subject of some public comment while the bill was being considered. The Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society ofCPAs came out strongly in favour of the reporting entity test. On balance, the committee concluded that the test proposed in the bill should be adopted, as the reporting entity test does not provide a test of sufficient certainty. The committee was further advised that the distinction made by the bill reflects overseas practice and experienceThere was a question as to whether the criteria proposedin the bill for distinguishing between small and large companies should be adopted in whole or in part. The test proposes that a company move from a sman company to large company when it meets two .of the following three criteria: more than 50 employees;gross operating revenue of more than $10 m-llion; or assyts of more than $5. million. The committee considered thaftestsof assets and turnover were more important than tests in relation to number of employees. While the committee was riot able to reach an unqualified view on the test, and believes the Attorney-General e Mr Lavarch), should give serious consideration to whether the 50 employees criteriii should be kept or should be deleted, leaving only the tests on assets and turnover, the government, in its response, indicated that it saw ,the present proposal as the being sufficiently flexible to ensure that the test was targeted in a manner which, to the government, seemed to be appropriate. But the government made it quite clear, in the Attorney-General's report: Having' said that, the Government has noted' carefully the committee's comments on these criteria and. will keep them under review. If the employees criteria proves to be inappropriate in practice, the Government will certainly be prepared to re-examine the issue. We welcome that commitment. I have mentioned it because we see it as a genuine comm.tment on the government's part and, if that further examination were required, we would expect that to occur. In relation to the other matters, the only important issue that I would like to advert to is the issue of having the register of debenture holders made public. It was a matter that caused some controversy and debate. Privacy is important. Various companies argued that the provisions could give an unfair advantage to banks, .n particular, as such information, in their hands, is not publicly available. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: Perth) (1.14 p.m.}-I support the amendments before the House, as I support the First Corporate Law SimplificatiQn Bill. I believe that the reSPQnse by' the AttQrneyGeneral(Mr Lava,rch) tQ the cQmmittee's repQrt and the ainendmentthat he has presented tQday cQnstitute an eminently sensible resPQnse tQ an eminently sensible cQmmitte.e repQrt. The AttQrney-General is tQbe CQmmended fQr that. I take this QPPQrtunity tQ briefly gQ thrQugh the fQrmal reSPQnse the AttQrney-General has made and alsQ the amendments. Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: I share some concerns that my colleague the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) expressed when he spoke on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994. My concerns relate to schedule 4, division SA, subsection (2). This is one of the· aspects of this bill that has received only general support. In fact, the committee's report says on page 17 at 2.37: The committee has been unable to reach an qualified view on the testthis is to do with the test for large and small companiesand believes that the Attorney-General should serious consideration to two options, namely the 50 employees criteria remain, or that the test more than 50 employees be deleted from the and the test for a small/large proprietary company be on the proposed assets and turnover criteria. I am disappointed and concerned that this section has not had greater consideration. The committee was advised by the corporate law simplification task force that, on the basis statistics provided by the ASC, 98 per cent proprietary companies would fall within the their business. small category and that it would be only two per cent of Australian companies that might get caught out having to report when it is necessary and having to do a full audit report at a high cost of somewhere between $10,000 to $30,000, according to the accounting which profession. So this subclause which addresses the distinction between small and large proprirequirements. etary companies callously disregards the one to two per cent of small and medium sized enterprises which will be disadvantaged by the introduction of this bill in the House today. I am disappointed about that. It is very ject. easy for us to throw figures around like one and two per cent, but when we consider that there are almost 800,000 small businesses in this country that means that 10,000 to 15,000 businesses stand to be disadvantaged by the measure in this bill. That is not good enough. As far as I am concerned, it is a fairly lier approach. There is no reason for this become a problem. There are other ways to deal with this issue. I think it does away with the whole spirit of what this bill is all that is, simplifying the Corporations Law. reason we want to see simplification of corporation law and other laws in relation to small business is to reduce the cost for small business of doing business and improve the profitability of small busine-s, and this simply does not address that issue. The committee stated in its findings, conclusions and recommendations, on page 33, paragraph 4.3, that the committee has been unable to reach an unqualified view. The unmembers were not able to totally agree. I do not think that the committee fully appreciated or understood the impact that this might have and the fact that that one to two per cent give translates into a very large number of small that businesses and affects quite a number of of people. One has to ask: who is responsible for bill law making in this country-the elected representatives of this place or the bureaucrats? While I appreciate that the bureaucrats make a powerful and very important contribution to the work of this House, ultimately we are the people's representatives and we are of out there understanding day to day the diffiof culties that people confront as they go about The flow-on effect of these tests will be to not increase the complexity of the law for this group of people; to increase the amount of paperwork and financial reporting required, no-one is going to be interested in; and to increase the cost to small businesses involved through the cost of unnecessary audit As I said, it could cost anything from $10,000 to $30,000. This will have the potential to needlessly increase small business costs by millions of dollars. That is not the aim of the corporate law simplification proI have had a letter this morning from one of the accounting bodies making the comment that the adverse implications that would flow from the implementation of the size test are that some small companies will escape their reporting obligations; some large companies cavawill be required to needlessly prepare acto counts; additional costs will be needed to identify business size; the overturning of the accounting standard for the reporting entity aboutthat was developed by the Australian AcThe counting Standards Board over a period of five years through a rigorous process more complex than the simplification process; it conflicts with the Corporations Law; and simplification simply has not been achieved.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: I will just pick up where I left off. I should have perhaps asked for the matters to be considered separately and then I would not have been interrupted in quite this way. If I can conclude the comments I was making on particularly the debenture matter, we are of the view that, the government having accepted that the ASC should be able to provide restrictions on access to venture registers and an amendment having been moved, it was worthy of support and it will have our support, as I indicated earlier. One of the other matters that I wanted to advert to briefly, which was picked up by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), was that of the single member companies as proposed under the bill. It would eliminate the silent director who is often the spouse and is often jointly responsible for company failure, even though they may not have been fully involved. That title 'sexually transmitted debt' was something that we had noted as well. In relation to auditors of proprietary companies, while less stringent requirement for appointment of auditors was of concern to the accounting bodies consulted, the committee accepted that that did not require amendment to the bill; rather, that the problem would be addressed by the accounting working party set up under the simplification process. As the government has given a guarantee that the working party will give full consideration to that issue, we welcome that undertaking. I understand that the government has accepted the recommendation from the committee that the inclusion of a small business guide should be reviewed by the Attorney-General after it has been in operation for a reasonable time. In relation to preparation of final financial reports and the recommendation that the ASC should prepare quarterly reports to the Attorney-General stating its reason for requiring small proprietary companies to prepare accounts, the government has indicated it will raise that matter with the chairman. That is a response that we have noted as well. There were other minor amendments, as outlined by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), and they do not present any difficult to us.

Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: I thank all members for their contribution. I think the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill and what it attempts to do is pretty strongly supported by both sides of the parliament. The honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan) is a fairly harsh taskmaster when it comes to her particular criticisms. Obviornly, when we move from a system which is in place to a new system of distinguishing between large and small companies and the sorts of requirements we put on both, some companies which are now enjoying the status of being an exempt proprietary company will be picked up and deemed to be large. But the test does very much target companies in terms of their economic significance. If a company has two of the three requirements-50 employees, an annual turnover of $10 million, and assets of $5 million-it is a relatively large and important commercial concern. I do not know whether it is unreasonable for the community to expect a somewhat more stringent level of disclosure in terms of the financial position and activities of those companies than for the vast majority which will get very great benefit out of this bill. The figures have been put at 98 per cent to two per cent, so it is the vast majority who are getting a much greater benefit. That is why the bill has been very warmly received by the small business community, at least as far as the views that have been expressed to me are concerned. There will be a small number affected. I do not know whether it is the 15,000 figure. That would be 15,000 companies which probably have more than 50 employees, but they would have to have 50 employees plus meet one of the other two tests as well. So I think it would actually be a figure somewhat less than that. The other matter which the honourable member for Pearce raised was the reporting entity concept which the accounting bodies are very attached to and have been for some years and which they promote very strongly. In fairness, one has to say that the vast balance of views of people in this areaparticularly the lawyers, in terms of the Law Council of Australia, and other advisers concerned with how these things can be made to work in a practical sense-is that the reporting entity concept is not a practical one to put into operation. If we are not now talking about a program, like it or not, the three criteria are at least fairly straightforward and simple and companies willlrnow whether they fall within it or not. The reporting entity concept is a far vaguer concept and, though it has some attractions, in my view and, indeed, in the view of the committee, the proposed tests are the way to go. These are new changes. It is a new area of law and we are trying some innovative things. As I have indicated, the government will review these changes very closely; We want to try to benefit, and get cost reductions for, business. We want innovative reforms that actually work. Therefore, we will watch this legislation very closely. If it is not working, if there are problems, if the thresholds are impacting on much larger numbers of companies in an adverse way, or if it is not in the public interest for the information to come out, we will change it. We are really trying to do a positive thing here. Mrs Moylan-How many years has it taken to get this bill up?

Speaker: Mr LAV ARCH
Title: AND SECONDARY EDUCATION
text: Two years, I suppose, since I have been Attorney-General. This was one of my major projects in terms of the simplification of the Corporations Law and it is relatively well advanced. The second stage will come out in a second bill in July. It will mean that, within probably another 18 months or so, the core provisions of the entire Corporations Law would have been rewritten. Quite honestly, I do not know if that is a bad achievement, given the complexity of what we were starting with. I thank members for their contributions and support. This is a good bill, and I commend the amendments to the House. Amendments agreed to. Bill, as amended, agreed to. Third Reading Bill (on motion by Mr Lavarch)-by leave-read a third time.
