Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Watson) (1.33 p.m.)I am very pleased to support the amendments that are before the House and I commend the government for them. I must say at the outset that I was surprised at the rather mean spirited remarks of the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), when he was responding on behalf of the opposition to the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott). The member for Goldstein seemed to think that there was something terrible in the fact that the government and the SMA had reconsidered the licensing fee that they were going to charge amateur radio operators. I will come back to that later in my contribution, but it is worthwhile putting on the record that the remarks were mean spirited. As members of parliament, rather than attacking the government for responding to people who make representations, we shoulp be commending the government and the government agency, instead of telling them that we are starting to keep a closer eye on them for doing this. These amendments will make it easier for apparatus licensees to pay their licence fees. They will now be able to make those payments annually for an apparatus licence, in instalments if they wish, and licences can be issued for a period of up to five years. That puts a little bit more certainty into these things for the licensees. Licensees will be able to have the choice of paying the total fee for the full period or paying by annual instalwhich ments. Formerly, a default in the payment of a licence fee-which was usually an up-front fee-would have resulted in the suspension cancellation of a licence. There was no scope to allow a licensee a period of grace in the payment of the fees. Often, people who needed these licences as an integral and ongoing part of their business could have been deprived of them through falling on hard times and suffering cash flow problems. These amendments make it a lot easier business. There are amendments which will introduce a system whereby people who default on an annual instalment will only lose their licences as a last resort. Licensees will now be able pay by instalment, paying interest on the late payment of fees and, if still in the balance of the licence fee for the entire period. As I said, the licence would only suspended or cancelled as a last resort. Those amendments to the bills are the result of a long and detailed public inquiry by Spectrum Management Agency. In 1993, in response to a report by the House of RepreThe sentatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, chaired by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), the government directed the Spectrum Management Agency to inquire into the restructuring of licence fees for cost recovery. The Spectrum Management Agency released a public discussion paper, held extensive public seminars and consulted the Wireless Institute of Australia and Radiocommunications Consultative Council. Over 4,000 submissions were received, and the amendments before us today are among the many key recommendations to emerge from that inquiry. The SMA plans to begin issuing five-year licences from April this year in line with the commencement of the radcom licensing computer system. It should be emphasised that these bills are intended to give apparatus licensees a choice, and give them flexibility in the way that they obtain their licences. They do not relate at all to the restructuring of the apparatus licence regime fee structure has caused some concern amongst sections of the community. As the chairman of the caucus committee on transport and communications I have or received representations expressing concern about some aspects of the SMA's draft proposal for the change to the fee structure, With a number of other government members--'-and also, I understand, some members of the opposition-I have made approaches to the government to have the proposed fee schedule re-examined. Rather than the mean spirited for way in which the member for Goldstein addressed this, I would like to commend the Spectrum Management Agency and the parliamentary secretary, because I am pleased to see that the SMA has further considered to the level of fees to be applied to amateurs in the light of the public benefit that amateurs default, pay provide to the community. A lower overall fee is now proposed by the be SMA in view of the training and the experience in communications technology that amateurs provide to young people, and the the role that amateurs provide in maintaining communication links in times of emergency. SMA has quite rightly decided to reduce the tax component of the licence fee to the minimum level. This will reduce the fee from the proposed $71 to $51 per annum. The fee would be applied to all amateur licences. While $51 represents a small increase on fees paid for many years by amateurs, the new fee is based on the administration and maintenance services provided to this group by the with SMA and includes the cost of issuing the the licences, managing interference to their services, issuing and registering call signs, accrediting examinations, and representing amateurs' interests in the international negotiations that the government carries on from time to time. It also represents a reduction of $20 from the draft fee which was proposed prior to the most recent round of consultations. While there are social benefits of amateur radio, the fee set at $51 represents more than fair value for their access to and ongoing use of large amounts of radio frequency spectrum. The important thing is that this reduction in the fee has not been shifted onto others, J because the change in the level of amateur fees will not be offset by an increase in the fees paid by other radiocommunications licensees. I think the parliamentary secretary and the SMA should be commended for· taking into account the work that amateurs do, both in times of national emergencies and in providing a very useful network that the community as a whole can take advantage of. People might recall that, during the bushfires in Sydney last year, people in the amateur radio area were involved in helping the State Emergency Service people. I think it was proper and reasonable for the government to take cognisance of the representations that were made, and it was proper and reasonable for the SMA to reflect that element in the fees that it charged. The changes to the fees for amateur radio operators are part of the broader change to apparatus licences. The fee structure proposal is just one of the results of the inquiry that the SMA conducted for all users of the radio frequency spectrum, not just amateur radio users. The government's objective is to establish an efficient and equitable means of managing this vital national resource. It is a resource that all Australians ought to share in, through the licensing of the spectrum. The changes to apparatus licences are designed to reduce the number of categories of licences, and to provide for a more equitable distribution of the charges that are already made for the use of the spectrum. The proposals put forward by the Spectrum Management Agency suggest fees based on a combination of the costs of administration and the value of the part of the spectrum being used. This method of charging is in line with the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, in which both the government and the opposition participated. Up until now, as honourable members would know, fees and categories of licensed radiocommunication equipment have developed in an ad hoc fashion, over time, with little relationship between the fees charged the spectrum used and the value of that spectrum. The cost to the Commonwealth of the administration and use of the public resource of the radio frequency spectrum should be reflected clearly in the pricing structure. That was one of the key findings of the public inquiry. Using this method, fees for some categories may rise, while some fees will fall. However, it should be stressed that no overall variation in revenue is being proposed. Fee concessions will be available to non-profit voluntary apparatus licensees who are primarily providing safety or human life services, such as rural firefighting and sea rescue. In broad terms, local governments and state governments could expect to benefit from the restructuring of the fees. Small businesses, such as taxi services and paging services, are also likely to see fee reductions. The government is fully aware of the concern-a concern, I might add, which has been preyed on by some opposition members, such as Senator Alston-that the proposed restructuring might result in higher fees being charged for amateur operators. They will be higher, but they will not be as high as was proposed, for the reasons that I outlined before. It is unfortunate that some people have been misleading the public by comparing the suggested fees for amateurs with the fees for CB radio operators, who are now covered by a class licence. It is a very unfair proposition, which is being put forward by some people in the community, to say that CB operators will have a very low one-off fee but amateur radio operators will have a higher fee. It should be made clear that CB and amateur operators are utilising quite different services, which both the government and international organisations provide. The CB users occupy very limited amounts of the spectrum, and they do not require any sort of frequency coordination. They can cut across each other and no-one can complain. There is no responsibility carried by the Spectrum Management Agency for interference investigation within the two bands subject to CB licences. The Spectrum Management for Agency's activities with regard to CB licences are confined to resolving interference by CB operators to other services, and investigating complaints of abusive or offensive language. On the other hand, amateur licensees generally occupy a part of the radio frequency spectrum that is highly sought after byalternative users. In Australia, they have access to 44 blocks of spectrum in 23 different bands. That is well above that available in most other countries, and very dramatically different from the amount of spectrum available to CB operators. Amateurs receive other services from the SMA, such as regular consultations with the Wireless Institute on variations and additions to spectrum availability. The SMA also represents amateurs' interests at international councils. If amateur operators were required to negotiate on their own behalf, they would have to bear a very heavy expense, and it would certainly cost a lot more than the extra $20 by which the licence fee has been increased. Amateur operators should remember that the SMA recently negotiated international licensing requirements on behalf of Australian amateur operators at no additional direct cost to them, other than the increase in their licence fee. The SMA also arranges and accredits examinations conducted by the Wireless Institute and provides comprehensive interference investigation for operators. That is an entirely different level of service from that provided to the gabble on the two CB bands. As I said earlier, amateur licensees sometimes assist in emergencies and provide their service as a public benefit. The government has recognised that by reducing some of the costs to amateur operators. However, there are many other radiocommunications users who also provide these services in emergencies, while continuing to pay very significant fees. However, the amendments today will facilitate a degree of flexibility in the radiocommunications licensing area that was not there before. That will be good for small business operators, it will be good for state and local authorities, and the reduction will be good for amateur radio operators. I commend the bill to the House and, in doing so, commend the parliamentary secretary for his responsiveness to calls from members on this side of the House and others for a sympathetic response to the plight of amateur operators. Many amateur operators are retired people. Others are disabled people who have taken this on as a way of communicating with the rest of the world, while housebound by their disability. Thus the government has helped business, local authorities and the amateur operators who put a lot of hard work in for the community.  specified by· the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) in his second reading speech, the main purpose of these amendments is to assist the implementation of a new apparatus licensing system, which has resulted from a public inquiry by the Spectrum Management Agency. It is important that, prior to making changes to the scheme that has governed radiocommunications in this country, we consider very carefully the role played by amateur radio operators in the industry and, more importantly, in the wider community, and how this bill may impact on them. Some 20,000 amateur radio operators in Australia provide a free community service, particularly in time of national disaster and emergency. After Cyclone Tracy, all communications with Darwin were provided by amateur radio networks. The Wireless Institute's civil emergency network, which is provided by amateur operators, is used during bushfires, floods and other disasters in New South Wales. The United States of America and many other countries recognise the value of amateur radio operators by issuing free licences, while Australian operators must pay one of the highest fees in the world. The Spectrum Management Agency planned to impose a tax on the radio spectrum used by amateurs by more than doubling the fee charged from $35 to $71. I am pleased to hear that the government has now backed away from that, and the in fees fee is now to increase to $51. The argument used by the SMA was that amateurs should be taxed according to the amount of spectrum they use. That argument does not hold water. The spectrum is fixed by international treaty, and the SMA has little say over the matter. It could not reallocate most of the amateur frequencies to commercial interests even if it wanted to. My understanding, after taking the time to talk to amateur operators in my electorate, is that the world is divided basically into three broad divisions for the purpose of management of the amateur radio spectrum as agreed by international treaty. It is in the Oceania division that Australia sits for the purpose of management. And it is management that we are talking about here today. What has been introduced is a new scheme of management for the spectrum, a scheme of fees categorised by either a spectrum maintenance charge or a spectrum access tax. The interesting point to note here is that the spectrum access tax is more of a spectrum denial fee. Primary spectrum users deny spectrum to other users and thus the charge of this fee or tax. This is okay if there is an alternative user for the spectrum, but in the spectrum allocated to amateur users the Spectrum Management Agency has no say on its use other than for amateur radio. The use of the spectrum for amateur radio is fixed by international treaty and thus is binding on Australia. I could, of course, go on to make comment on this government's almost blind adherence to every treaty that has ever come into existence, but I will refrain from that. What I do find hard to swallow is the tale that the government should be trying to tax the use of amateur spectrum on the basis of exclusion when it has no mandate or authority in any manner to allow any use for that particular spectrum other than amateur use. As to these spectrums, many are fixed as exclusively amateur worldwide and are of no commercial value to Canberra. Most of the others are already assigned to commercial or government primary users and to amateurs as secondary. Once again, the SMA cannot vary the amateur usage because that is covered by international treaty. On another point, there are some 300,000 CB radio operators in Australia. They do not have to pass an examination, yet the amateur radio operators have to pass three exams at a 70 per cent pass level in order to gain. a certificate. Some CB operator- use their stations and repeaters for business, while amateur radio operators are forbidden to do so by law. The licence fee for CB operators has been abolished. The question has to be asked: why should amateur radio operators have to pay when CB users do not? The distinct role and position of the amateur radio operator as a competent professional and a controlled operator is very clear. I recently visited amateur radio operators VK6 VX, VK6 VHI and VK6 XX in Albany in Western Australia and I was impressed with the lise that is now being made of computers linked into amateur radio networks, in particular the ability of these amateurs to operate programs which not only show the track of satellites, including the one that I observed of a Russian space station passing over Albany at the time, but also are able to communicate with those stations. Both NASA and the Russian authorities have recognised the value of the amateur radio network by incorporating those links into the space station and shuttle programs. On a more important note, I was able to see the message traffic that was generated out of the Kobe earthquake disaster, straight after that terrible earthquake struck that city. The residents of that city would no doubt have been thankful that the amateur radio network was in place to pass their cries for help worldwide. We have a situation under this scheme where one of the ongoing effects will be to double the user fee for our amateur radio operators. Coming from an electorate of over 28,000 square kilometres, I recognise the true value of the amateur radiocommunication network. The government should reconsider its position on amateur radio operators and recognise the immense value of their work in the community and not impose this increase to this particular area. Indeed, as I mentioned, the government really should look at the huge value of the amateur radio operators to the community.

Speaker: Mr FORREST
Title: COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Here we 'have another example of this government's propensity to tax the community of Australia with absolutely no mandate whatsoever. We have these bills before us today, with titles which all include the word 'taxes'; the Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Amendment Bill, the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill, and the Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Amendment Bill. It seems that this government has an unbelievable preoccupation with tax, trying to satisfy an insatiable thirst for revenue. There is a suggestion that everything that moves, and sometimes even everything that dies, amendment to that. should be taxed; and not only taxed here, but taxed at a whole variety of different points. I have spent 20 months in this parliament, Mr Deputy Speaker; and given what I remember of the March 1993 election, I would say that if this government has any mandate whatsoand ever it is not to increase taxes. But here have another example of its preoccupation. The government is so preoccupied with taxing that it wants to tax hobbies. I have noted that the government has responded to what has been a fairly massive degree of representation, and I have noted most members have received letters from been persons within their own electorates who are amateur and ham radio operators. think the government can take too much credit for reducing a proposed increase in its tax on amateur radio operators. All it has done is to reduce it by $20. It is still an increase in a tax on a hobby. I can appreciate that there are other ments, and that the purpose of this legislation is to enable some flexibility in the payment annual licence instalments. There may be some merit in that, and to that extent the coalition is not opposing these bills. However, my namesake, the honourable member for find  government to reconsider its intent to tax group of Australians who make a contribution exercise. to our community. I would like to take the opportunity later to demonstrate that it valuable contribution. The government ought to consider what it might cost a government to provide the sorts of resources in terms public safety and contribution to public events that are provided by ham and amateur radio operators. Indeed, when it is considered that the annual revenue from licence renewals is something around $100 million per year, it is clear that it is already a significant source of revenue for the government, so I was particularly annoyed to see the Spectrum Management Agency proposing initially to double licence fees. I was at least somewhat relieved to hear the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott), when he introduced these bills, say that there has been some The Spectrum Management Agency currently supervises about 250,000 radio licences. The fees for these have in the past varied from $18 a year for smaller marine licences for CB and VHF operators to some huge we amounts for multiple public mobile telecommunication services, fees for which often amount to several hundreds of dollars--even $700,000 per year on big installations. I want to address the assistance that is provided by amateur radio operators, particularly in emergency situations. The support that they provide to community organisations has a consistent part of their ethos, and has been promoted by radio operators as part of I do not that ethos for decades. One of the other valuable contributions-I have a notable number of international radio operators in my own electorate-is the contribution they make to the worldwide promotion of goodwill because of their community and eleinternational communications. I have been informed by some of them that, when they of have made comments about this increase to some of their international corresponders via the radio spectrum, other amateur operators in other countries are completely surprised to that this country wants to introduce such a dramatic increase in fees. I think it ought to a be labelled as a cynical revenue raising I note that the previous speaker, the memis a ber for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay), called us cynical and mean spirited in the contributions that we have already made to this debate. The of only mean spirited people that the community of Australia ought to be alerted to are those who occupy the government benches. It is unbelievably mean spirited of them to tax community and amateur operators out there who, as I have said, provide such a valuable contribution to this community. The Radiocommunications Act 1992 made provision for people such as community amateur radio operators because it included 'adequate provision for use by public or community services'. The act also requires' a responsive and flexible approach to meeting the needs of users'. The substantial increase in licence fees causes me great concern because of its inconsistency with existing provisions of the act. From that I formed my own conclusion about what a cynical tax raising exercise this is turning out to be. None of my corresponders are encouraged by the government's recent announcements that the amount of the increase is to be reduced. They still maintain that, as amateur radio operators who provide a valuable communication facility to train personnel in what is an important area of communications, their role should be recognised. As the member for Forrest said, I would urge this government to reconsider that particular part of the legislation because it is completely unfair. I see no justification whatsoever in taxing this particular narrow group of people who are confined by the fact that they are a captive audience because they have fixed locations which are easy to find and, therefore, easily sourced for taxation revenue increases.  is VK 3PM, was one of my corresponders. I would like to quote parts of his letter to me in order to make his complaint part of the public record. He introduces his letter by referring to the proposed changes by the Spectrum Management Agency. He then says: Amateur radio is a recreational and educational "hobby" pursued by a wide range of people in our community. Amateur Radio is of immense benefit to the community. There are many instances where it has played crucial and important part in providing emergency communications where civil and military systems have been unable to perform. He then provides examples of communications with respect to Cyclone Tracy in Darwin, recent bushfires in many of our states and past earthquakes in New South Wales. He goes on: It is a hobby that produces effective selftraining in technology. Many young people graduate to a career in electronics having had their ambitions developed through such an interest. The Scouts and Guides movements of Australia have many stations used in training of their youth. There is immense social value in a recreational hobby particularly suited to handicapped persons and also senior citizens. I continue to quote from Mr Milne's letter. He states: The Amateur Radio Service provides a ready pool of trained personnel available for service to the country ... I would emphasise just how important the contribution of amateur radio operators is in rural areas, especially in an area like mine which is 70,000 square kilometres, one-quarter of the north-west of Victoria. The letter c()ntinues: Australian Amateur radio operators are among the world leaders in development of new technology and have recently made significant contributions to research in areas such as satellite technology and radio propagation studies. The hobby provides a valuable service in development of international relations. There are many more positive aspects that could be mentioned. He sought my support to have the proposed fee increases rescinded. He has that support, and he has the support of all of us on this side of the House. It is quite clear that in terms of amateur radio the government ought to have made more appropriate allowances. Mr Milne's letter refers to some of the community benefits of amateur radio, but there are many others which are impossible to measure in dollar terms. You could not measure in dollar terms the benefit of amateur community radio. Therefore, I find it unbelievable that the government would let its insatiable thirst for revenue override such a benefits and that it would propose a cost to services when it has not even considered what it would cost the government to provide such services. I would like to draw attention to a particuincrease lar, huge community event that occurs in my electorate. It is the Murray River marathon. The marathon starts as far upstream the Murray River as Albury and ends in Swan Hill, which is the city in which I reside. The role that amateur radio and the communication networks play that ensures the community and public safety of that event is just one example of which I am already aware of the benefit of amateur radio operators. If we get back to the more particular focus of this legislation, like many other pieces legislation brought to this House, it is .all about tax-for goodness sake, tax it; tax it it moves! Fuel tax is an unbelievable impost that affects everything we do, particularly those in rural Australia. I am reminded government's obfuscation during its last election campaign when it had those TV advertisements with cash registers popping at the sight of a tube of toothpaste showing extra 15 per cent tax. That was a complete obfuscation of the truth, and it completely overlooked the fact that the government's policy was to remove seven taxes and have only one fair and balanced tax. So, if government has any mandate, it is not to increase taxes. Tax it if it dies! Every year in pre-budget deliberations, we hear about death duties inheritance tax. Tax it if it burns! We recently heard intonations from the government that it wanted to introduce a carbon tax. Thankfully considered. that was knocked on the head. It would have imposed more on-costs to business in this country. Tax it if you sell it-wholesale sales tax! Tax it again if you buy it! The dramatic increases we have seen in the last 20-odd months in wholesale sales tax completely surpass anything we had originally proposed or intended with the goods and services tax. Tax it if it gains value-a capital gains tax! Now we hear suggestions that if it sleeps it will be taxed-a bed tax. What an imposition that is going to be on the valuable industry of this nation. When it comes to amateur radio, I think it is outrageous and completely unfair. The government ought to reconsider. It has given some reconsideration, but I think it ought not at all this particular component of amateur radio. My understanding of taxation is that tax ought to be levied on a profit or a likely profit. I remind the government that licence by regulation would prohibit amateur radio operators having a profit. So how could taxing it be right? Tax on the use of radio spectrum, which is already set aside by international convention for amateur radio, does not occur in any other country. So it is completely unfair, unjust and flies in the face of of practice in other countries. From what I hear, we are already something of a laughing if stock in the international communities in which amateur radio communicates. No other country in the world levies such a tax on their of the amateur radio operators. Is the government really aware of the size of the group it wants to antagonise by the up introduction of this tax and the powerful an communication facility they have available to communicate a message about the lack of mandate this government has to tax them? last Currently, there are about 18,000 amateur radio operators and, internationally, their this numbers are measured in miIIions-a huge communication network. They have powerful radiocommunications at their disposal-they talk a lot. As I said, already international and reaction is not favourable on this government's intent to tax them. This particular aspect of this legislation has been grossly iIIAgain, because amateur radio operators are a registered minority, they are an easy target. I refer again to Mr Milne's letter where he asks for my support to see what I can do about ensuring that these increases are not imposed. In his letter he says: I require your support towards action to have the proposed fees rescinded and another more suitable approach taken. We would consider it an excellent result if we were granted licences free of charges as is the case in the United States where the community, education and recreational value of tourist Amateur Radio is highly valued. I assure Mr Milne that I do oppose this unjust form of tax. The government ought not hide behind its statement that this legislation is all about a positive gesture of allowing greater flexibility in the payment of radio licence charges. I recognise and support professional and large radio licence operators having their fees reduced by taking up payment options. My particular objection is that I consider amateur radio operators an important group of Australians who have a function to fulfil. The package was developed as a result public inquiry which was initiated as far back as December 1993 at the direction of the government. This package aims to respond to industry requirements resulting from that inquiry into that more flexible arrangement, so I support that aspect. The options introduced by the package coincide with a whole new licensing computing system and will therefore provide a much clearer and easier administration. At least that part to meet some of the aspirations of the indusSMA try. But nowhere in the legislation or in reading the background information do I find any justification for the 'punitive' attitudes towards amateur radio operators. I do not think they ought be used to subsidise some the gains that might be achieved for other licensed operators. I remind the government that we will every opportunity to remind them that it has no mandate to increase taxes on Australians. We bitterly oppose these arrangements and certainly take offence at a bill like this which seeks to call increases in tax revenue through licence fees 'revenue gaining exercises'. are simply taxes and they cost Australians, and we are opposed to that.

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Title: COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Capricornia) (2.14 p.m.)Mr Deputy Speaker, I am pleased to contridebating-the bute to this debate on the Radiocommuniment cations (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendtus ment Bill 1994 and cognate bills. I was disappointed to hear the comments of the radio member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) who, I know, is concerned about all issues that may impact on his constituents. I believe he is not pretions. senting the full facts. I dare say that the criticism in relation to this bill goes back 18 January when the shadow minister for the communications and the arts, Senator Alston, took hlp this issue in a press release. He It is difficult to avoid the conclusion that amateur operators have the misfortune to be a disciplined, individually licensed service and, therefore, an easy target for revenue raising . . . And it goes on and on. While we all recognise the contribution made to the community by amateur radio hams, the opposition spokesperson failed to indicate that he had any idea of of what was in the report of the Spectrum ManagementAgency. He said that it indicated that there had been no consultation. The facts are at variance with that statement. Indeed, if the member for Mallee had cared to look at the information, he would have been able to new payment clarify the situation. On 8 December 1993 the then communications minister, the present Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall), instituted the inquiry. seems Throughout January and February 1994, the distributed over 4,000 copies of the discussion paper to interested parties, advertised widely and then proceeded to conduct 14 public seminars attended by over 900 people. It received 422 submissions and reported its of findings to the then Minister for Communications and the Arts, the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator take Collins), at the end of May 1994. At every stage of the proceedings there was close consultation with the Institute of Wireless Operators. Indeed, it was very involved when this issue was being looked at. There is hardly a case for saying that there has been They no consultation. There has actually been widespread consultation. The general line being presented is that the whole basis of the legislation we are now report of the Spectrum ManageAgency, titled Inquiry into the apparalicence system: a new outlook---came very about because we have a down on amateur operators in this country. In fact, as is quite clear from the report, the reforms go to the whole management of radio communicaYesterday, when the Parliamentary Secreto tary to the Minister for Communications and Arts (Mr Elliott) introduced these bills, he made it clear that the licence for amateurs said: would be a flat rate of $51; the original proposal for $71 had been just that, only a proposal. The reforms are widespread and very pertinent to the handling of this area of operation. The report includes a number of recommendations. In relation to citizens band licences, there was a recommendation, adopted in October 1994, for class licences. Other recommendations include: the simplification of apparatus licence categories; arrangement for licence terms up to five years with very flexible payment arrangements---one of the key factors in the bills we are debating; the possibility of transferring apparatus licences between parties; and, very importantly, licence fee .concessions for volunteer non-profit emergency organisations, such as rural firefighters, search and rescue organisations, coastguards, surf lifesavers and ambulance services in remote areas. Then there was a definite decision to charge for a range of services provided. by the Spectrum Management Agency. Those charges are to be introduced on an equitable and transparent basis so that people can understand what the charges are for and why they are paying them. What irks me is that the opposition parties continually bleat about government charges and cutting government expenditure. But the minute there is a specific option for user pays principles, .for making sure that services are provided and that the government is accountable, they are bleating about how shocking it is that we are raising another tax. I believe this is very unfair. I am sure all other honourable members have made representations on behalf of amateur radio operators. I take the time and trouble to find out the facts. Unfortunately, it seems that some of my colleagues in the opposition-and particularly the shadow minister-have decided that it is easier to score a cheap political point than to go and make a proper investigation. The shadow minister is the person who would like to be running this area of the government. This is a wide ranging report which has a number of very positive reforms for the use of the spectrum. All the shadow minister can talk about is this one small point. No-one in this country wants to pay taxes but everybody wants services. Local amateur radio operators in my area felt this was an impost. I am sure they will be delighted with the very sensible decision made by the government. It is not about not charging them. Our amateur radio operators have done all the good things that my colleague the honourable member for Mallee suggested. I have no argument with all those good things. While the amateurs were paying limited fees for the services they received, other essential services were paying much greater charges. One of the key. benefits in these reforms is that a lot of these essential services will have a decrease in charges. That is a very sensible rationalisation. I refer to the editorial by Jim Rowe in the March 1995 edition of Electronics Australia. Mr Rowe indicated that he had lots of representations from amateur radio operators. He has taken a very responsible position. He says: Amateur licence fees haven't risen for about 10 years, even though the cost of most other goods and services have risen quite significantly in that time. Some sort of rise was probably inevitable. He goes on to say that there will be increasingly fierce competition for space in the electromagnetic spectrum. He says: In many ways this is a finite resource, and historically amateurs have accumulated quite a lot of spectrum 'real estate'. In fact I understand that in Australia, amateurs are second only to the Department of Defence in terms of their total allocation of spectrum space. He goes on further: The SMA has sought to base them clearly on the real costs of issuing and renewing licences, and also on managing each licensee's activities-together with a 'spectrum access cost' or tax, based on the perceived value of the spectrum segment(s) being used on an exclusive basis. On the whole this seems reasonable, and is in factthe kind of changes taking place in many other countries as well. This is rather interesting: The problem for amateurs is that because quite a lot of spectrum is allocated to them, applying this rationale strictly 'across the board' would result in amateur licence fees rising to well over $500 per year. If we really wanted to put in place a user pays principle, that is the sort of charge that would be allocated because, as Jim Rowe says, a significant amount of spectrum is allocated to amateur operators. The other issue that has to be taken into consideration is that, if you are going to get into this hobby, which has lots of positive spin-offs, including emergency availability when there is an accident or a major disaster-and I commend the comments of my colleague the member for Mallee in this matter-the equipment will cost you at least $2,000. It is a considerable investment for people who choose to become involved or interested in this area or hobby. Therefore, a charge of $51, or even $70, would not seem to me to be a major impost. One of the concerns brought to me that I responded to was about what appeared to be a sudden jump. Jim Rowe-and I assume he knows a great deal more about this area than I do-finishes his article by saying: It might well be prudent for amateurs to swallow hard and accept this fee rise, without much fuss. Attracting a lot of interest might cause renewed demands for some of that precious spectrum space, by potential users willing to pay a lot more privilege. That has not really been taken into consideration by some of our operators, for very wellarea, intentioned reasons, but it has also not been taken into consideration for what I would consider fairly cheap political reasons by some members of the opposition, particularly by the person who would like to be making the decisions in this area-Senator Alston. If we look at the suggested reforms licensing types, we see very clearly that this report has done a very good job. It has a very good job because there said before, this wide ranging consultation. There was a commitment that this consultacommunity tion would continue in relation to a range issues, including the cost to amateurs. Page 5 states: of the SMA discussion paper suggested that the licence types should be: workable in number; clear, simple and mutually exclusive; able to accommodate new developments in technology and service delivery; be consistent with SMA management functions, such as planning, applying licence conditions and setting fees; and . be administered efficiently (for example, by automation). Thus, as a general principle, there should be a minimal number of 'broad purpose' licence types. This approach is consistent with the majority of submissions to the inquiry. In fact, it came up with a grouping of 16 new transmitter licence types with three new receiver licence types which would be based on definitions in the Australian spectrum plan. I just want to go through those briefly to indicate the breadth of areas we are talking about. The first area is aeronautical. The second area is aircraft. The third area is amateur, and within amateur are several subgroupings: unrestricted, limited, novice, intermediate, novice limited, amateur beacon and amateur repeater. They are allocated a proposed differing amount. The fourth area is broadcasting, which includes broadcast service and narrowband area service. The other areas are defence; earth; fixed; land mobile; maritime coast; maritime ship; multipoint distribution station, MDS; outpost; public telecomfor the munications service; radiodetermination; scientific; and space. We are talking here about a very important particularly with the increase in high tech and communications looking for areas of the frequency. I believe the amateurs continue to have a very fair operation. The sorts of licences we are intending to provide under this bill indicate that we are prepared to be very flexible about the way those payments to are made-to make it much easier, for instance, for retired hams to be able to make done those payments. I believe we have done a has been, as I very good job here. I want to further comment on the public or service providers. One of the of recommendations in the report on page 11 The SMA considers that concessions should apply to volunteer, non profit, emergency organisations involved in rural fire fighting, search and rescue, coast guard and surf life saving activities (principally providing safety of human life services) and to individuals who support such organisations. Organisations involved in ambulance services in remote areas will also qualify for concessions. The sorts of concerns that have been raised by a number of people, including the amateurs, have' certainly been considered in this report. The government and the agency have responded to a range of calls from the community about the method of charging, which has been suggested is in line with recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and the public inquiry process. Some concerns were put to me about the fact that citizens band radio holders had been provided with a class licence. But, from information given to me, it is clear that the CB bands - although they appear to very numerous--occupy a relatively small part of the spectrum and do not require the sort of regulation or representation the SMA has made on behalf of the Wireless Institute of Australia in terms of the accreditation of their examinations and international representations. Although it would appear to individual amateur radio operators on the ground that the Spectrum Management Agency does little for them, a great deal is done on behalf of this group of people-which is about 20,000 across the country. However, this means that about 30 per cent of licensees would experience fee increases-this is where the amateur licence holders are found. Local government authorities, state governments and the emergency service organisations will benefit considerably, as will organisations such as taxi operators and paging services-those small businesses about which the opposition claims to be very concerned. Although I can understand the concerns of amateurs in terms of the CB network, the facts really speak for themselves. I return now to the amount of spectrum - hat is available. Amateurs occupy a great deal of the spectrum--44 blocks in 23 different bands, which is well above what is generally available in other countries. So there are 20,000 amateurs with 179 times more spectrum than the estimated 800,000 CB operators. Each amateur uses significantly more power than CB users. As I said before, amateurs occupy more spectrum than most others, except the Department of Defence, which I think we would all agree would require a fair degree of spectrum. The government, through its consultations, has certainly listened to the voice of a relatively small group, and that is the art of politics. The amateurs have lobbied their members, we have made representations and the government has decided to respond by making it a flat rate, which I believe is realistic and reasonable. I hope that all the amateurs will be very happy with that resolution. We have not backed down or buckled under pressure, and we hear this nonsense ad infinitum and ad nauseam from the opposition. This has been a process of consultation for more than 12 months, and there have been further consultations. In my view, it is a good decision and I hope we will hear less froni the opposition of this nonsense about another tax.

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I am sure the coalition responds favourably to the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) saying that we are about fiscal responsibility in managing the financial affairs of the government. There is no question about that, but sometimes it gets back to a matter of priority. One of my early tasks as a member was to sit on the Public Accounts Committee. It was there that I began to see some of the horrifying mismanagement that was occurring. I am sure that if the member for Capricornia discussed this matter with some of her colleagues they would find some very large savings in very many areas so they do not have to be mean spirited with a group of amateur people. During 1994 a review of radiocommunications apparatus licensing was conducted by Spectrum Management Agency. One of the recommendations arising from that review was that a wider variety of payment options be made available, particularly to avoid the necessity for regular annual licence tax payments when the term of the licence exceeds one year. On the surface, it is a very commendable market driven recommendation. However, I wonder how many members of this House are aware of other activities of the Spectrum Management Agency that make the implication of a wider variety of tax payment options almost a <necessity for many of Australia's 18,115 amateur radio licence holders. For these clients of the Spectrum Management Agency, the amendments contained in the radiocommunications bills are, unfortunately, timely. These individuals are faced with the spectre of a new tax on their access to the radio frequency spectrum. Until yesterday, amateur radio licence holders were faced with a new tax of $30 per year - equal to 273 per cent of the annual reissue costs of $11 per year, or 94 per cent of the total administration charge of $32 per year, or 73 per cent of the total annual amateur licence fee of $41 per year. Yesterday the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), came into this House and subsequent- Dear Judi, ly, in yet another about-face by the government, announced more policy on the run. Amateur radio operators are now faced with a total annual fee of $51, a 38 per cent or increase on the current $37 fee. This will be a 400 per cent increase on the 1980 fee, when amateur radio licence fees were $10 per annum. Let us not be deceived by this cynical about-face by the government. Firstly, as I will outline later, this amazing $20 reduction merely removes a blatant act of discrimination against amateur radio operators. On behalf of my constituents, I am very pleased that the government has bowed to the pressure. I have had very many representations from my electorate on this issue. It is good to see the public getting involved and applying pressure to make appropriate changes. Most importantly, the government's real agenda in this case has been exposed: that is, to tax the amateur radio industry out of existence. This industry will now be left to wonder when the next act of government taxing will focus on its members. It is little wonder that the SMA has implemented some innovative payment schedules to accommodate the payment of the tax on the issue of a receiver licence. Item 2 of the schedule of the Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1994 inserts proposed new section 6, which gives applicants for receiver licences issued for periods of more than 12 months different options in relation to the payment of the tax. This is all well and good, but it does not address the concerns of those individuals who hold amateur radio licences. They are in many instances young or elderly members of the community. They may be retired war veterans or simply individuals participating in a very worthwhile hobby. Perhaps they belong to the many hundreds of scout and guide groups around Australia. I know of at least 85 scout and guide groups that are registered amateur radio operators. Perhaps members opposite would like to hear of the concerns of the Girl Guides Association in Western Australia, which wrote to me on 27 February: The Girl Guides Association in Western Australia was most perturbed to hear of the forthcoming increases in fees for amateur radio station licences. $14 The guides and scout associations both have stations which are used for the training of younger members. Jamboree of the Air could not function without the assistance of a large pool of amateur radio operators. A peculiar thing about this whole increase is that over Australia the increase in revenue to the Spectrum Management Agency would only amount to $495,000 per annum. The Spectrum Management Agency have announced that CB operators would have their licence fees completely waived. This means that Spectrum Management Agency has given up a revenue of around $3.6 miIIion per annum. As CB operators can use their radio equipment for financial gain as against the amateur's purpose of training and personal intercommunications and, in the case of the guides and scouts, increasing friendship between them and member in other states and countries, it is odd to say the least at the reasoning behind these two decisions. We request your support towards action to have the proposed fees rescinded. That group has my support on that, despite the fact that I am concerned about decreasing benefits for the small business community. I do not think the way to do it is to penalise those in our community who not only operate radios as a hobby but also give back a tremendous community service. On the government's way to the new tax market, a funny thing has happened. The government has decided that the commercial intere!)ts associated with CB operators, and the millions of dollars forgone in licence revenue from that market, are somehow made up for by the easy pickings of the amateur radio sector. This is the sort of inequity the community has come to expect from this government. For amateur radio operators, the SMA's new tax payment options contained in the bill are not the only issues foremost in their mind. They are really concerned about whether or not they will be able to continue to afford to hold amateur radio licences at all. In its publication entitled Inquiry into the Apparatus Licence System-A New Outlook, the Spectrum Management Agency lists its annual apparatus licence fees. Of the 15 categories listed, the SMA states: The minimum spectrum access tax is proposed to be $10. All except three of the non assigned licence sub types will attract the minimum tax. It should come as no surprise to honourable members that the three licences that were to attract a higher fee were all amateur radio licences. The fees for amateur radio licences were to be 200 per cent higher-$30. What possible justification was given? None. Of all the categories listed only one has a higher total fee than amateur radio. The remainder are at least 37 per cent lower, and some of them are as much as 66 per cent lower. What responsible authority would impose such an inequity on a community good? Better still, what sort of government would allow this to be imposed on such a valuable community resource? As indicated yesterday, the government has been caught out. It has been exposed. The SMA's lame duck excuse that this last minute about-face is the result offurther consultation and consideration is simply perpetuating the myth that the SMA is concerned about amateur radio. Its actions clearly reveal otherwise. This is the action of a mean-spirited government that is surreptitiously eroding the quality of life for many Australians. In fact, I think it is called robbing Peter, who is the community, to pay for the excesses of Paul, who is the part-time Prime Minister. The SMA's 273 per cent tax would have raised approximately $550,000 from a community sector that contributes hundreds of hours every year-worth hundreds of thousands of dollars-to a voluntary and free community service. The great bulk of this service just happens to be provided during times of crisis in the community and at a time when other traditional and commercial lines of communication are often not functioning. In many other countries this service is not taxed at all. In the United States, Congress has recognised the importance of amateur radio and, consequently, no licences and no taxes are paid by amateur radio operators. But this is not so in Australia. This government's concept of the clever country is to impose a 273 per cent tax on the activities of our scouts, our guides and committed radio enthusiasts, who have repeatedly demonstrated excellence and commitment to the use and development of amateur radio in Australia and overseas. It must also be emphasised that the amateur radio community operates in true amateur spirit. Unlike other users of the radio frequency spectrum, amateur radio licensees are prohibited from gaining any pecuniary interest from their activities. This government is using amateur radio. Perhaps it could be suggested that the government is blatantly exploiting the goodwill and the commitment of this sector of the community and, in the process, is determined to squeeze every bit of financial gain possible from it. A very clear comparison of the government's commitment to the community is evident when one looks at the discriminatory way amateur radio users are treated as compared with the way users of citizens band frequencies are treated. CB users have had their licence requirements abolished. That is a windfall of approximately $6.5 million to users of the radio frequency spectrum. It must be noted that the CB users are often commercial operators who do gain financially from their investments. As I said before, as the shadow minister for small business, I am the last one who wants to see any additional costs imposed, but I believe this particular measure is inequitable. The bills being debated today provide the SMA with the power to determine the amount of tax in respect of the issue of receiver and transmitter licences. I believe it would be automatically assumed that with this power would come responsibility. From the activities of the SMA it not only appears that it does have difficulty in developing equitable taxing and licensing regimes but it also appears, from the information provided by industry participants, that certain senior SMA staff have a great deal of difficulty clearly articulating the SMA's actions, intentions and services to a very well-informed community sector. Concern has been expressed that a misinformation campaign has been embarked upon to cloud the waters of change. This is evident in a transcript from an interview with a senior executive of SMA, who it is alleged provided the following commentary on radio station 5CK at Port Pirie in South Australia on 21 February 1995: What we do is to maintain the same level of revenue and to redistribute that revenue based on a fair and equitable basis. It is true that much amateur spectrum is decided by International Treaty, but that's not to say that Governments can't and in fact shouldn't charge. Most governments around the world do, although there are some that don't. The Wireless Institute of Australia responded to that statement as follows: We know of no other government that makes a charge to amateur radio operators for access to the spectrum. Some do charge a fee for a station licence whilst in some countries no charge is made at all. Australia would be creating a world precedent by applying a Spectrum Access Tax. I believe that (Mr Grant) the SMA executive is being at the least, deliberately misleading here and could possibly be accused of telling a complete lie. Unfortunately, that was not the only extract from that interview that drew outrage from the amateur radio community. I refer to the fact that these bills provide the SMA with the power to determine the amount of tax in respect of the issue of a receiver licence. The SMA has certainly learnt very quickly how to apply that power. At a recent presentation the SMA identified its revenue estimates for 1995-96. Depending on your point of view it is either interesting or disturbing information. From the point of view of amateur radio operators it is a disgusting example of blatant tax grab. Based on the following figures, I would have to agree. The SMA's revenue forecasts are: 17 per cent from spectrum maintenance charge; three per cent from licence renewal charges; 14 per cent from licence issue charges; two per cent from consuitancies; and-wait for it-64 per cent or $60.6 million from spectrum access tax. The figures indicate beyond any doubt that the primary activity of the SMA is as a tax gathering front for the government. Unfortunately the amateur radio community is deemed to be a soft touch. The SMA, in its publication titled Inquiry into the apparatus licence system-a new outlook, states: As noted earlier, all fees are in fact taxes levied under the Tax Acts. The basis for imposing a spectrum access tax on users, above the costs of spectrum management is that the spectrum is a valuable resource and the community is entitled to a monetary return--or a rent-for its private use. A direct monetary return, via government, is of the intended to compensate the community for the user benefiting from access to spectrum. It is also a rationing device. In respect of amateur radio, the SMA should practice what it preaches when it refers to valuable resource. In February 1995, the SMA stated: The SMA appreciates the good work done by the amateur radio enthusiasts in providing services at various times to assist the community. It is also aware of the benefits in encouraging young people to learn about radio. The SMA should remember those sentiments and then reconsider its bizarre treatment of this very valuable community resource. The SMA should also listen to others in the community who have commented on the value of the amateur radio network. I would recommend that those on the other side of the House also take note-wherever they are today. In October 1992, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), addressed the SEANET convention in Darwin. He said: The work carried out by amateurs when Darwin was ravaged by a cyclone on Christmas Day in 1974 was outstanding. There was virtually a total loss of communications with the outside world. When telecommunication links were cut, nothing was heard from Darwin for a number of hours until the lone voice of a Darwin amateur made contact with other amateur operators. Amateur radio operators must surely feel that they are now a lone voice in the ears of government and its cohort in this tax exercise, the SMA. I ask the member for the Northern Terridemn tory, now that the chips are down for amateur radio people, where does his support lie? should have a caucus with his colleagues, the member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), the ber for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans), the member for Makin (Mr Duncan) and the member for Dickson (Mr Lavarch). I am told they have all offered support to the amateur radio industry. It would appear to be very hollow and ineffectual support if they are prepared to stand up and publicly be counted on this issue. One final commendation that sums up the contribution and community value of the amateur radio community is provided by the Acting Chief Commissioner Robert of the Victoria Police. With respect to the 1993 Victorian floods he said: The effort by the Wireless Institute Civil cy Network volunteers and the fact that they volunteers who provide their own time and sources is to be highly commended as in such circumstances it would have been extremely difficultto complete the registration of evacuees by any other method. These accolades are given to a valuable community resource. That this government and the SMA seek to tax it out of existence is nothing short of a national disgrace. Like my colleagues, I have had numerous constitutelecommunications ents express their anger and concern at outrageous tax imposts being thrust on amathe teur radio communities. The views and spirit of the amateur radio community are best summed up by one of my constituents who said: We are proud of our history and our achievement but realise that keeping ourselves very much to ourselves for so long we're in danger of becoming just another endangered species! That communication was received from Mr Harry Atkinson who, in his own words, is radio. blind, aged 81 years, and still kicking-a great Australian. The coalition supports these amendments. I endorse the comments made by my colleague. I am pleased to see that the government has had a change of matter in the last few days. No doubt that has this been brought about by enormous public pressure and pressure by many of my colleagues in relation to this matter. I do conthe actions and attitudes of this government and the SMA for their joint attack on He the Australian amateur radio community.

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL
text: One memwould think that amateur radio was being taken out of existence when one listens to the opposition in this debate on the radiocommunications bills. It is not. In these days of instant communications, there are a growing number of uses of the radio frequency not spectrum and a large number of users. It has been of interest to me to see how quickly mobile phones have been adopted as the norm in telephone communications. I see kids on roller blades chatting away on mobiles, pretend or otherwise. Suddenly, these things Falconer are all part of our life. We Australians seem to love technology and we take up the use of it faster than just Emergenabout any other nation. How we managed are without the facsimile machine is anybody's reguess. I cannot imagine life now without a computer. Television was introduc.ed in my lifetime. I remember the old Astor set being carried into my house. Radiocommunications is more than an industry in its own right; it forms part of another complex communications system and provides an essential transmission medium for carriers and broadcasters. the Radiocommunications systems also provide invisible sinews for other industrial sectors including transport, defence, emergency services, mining, agricultural, commerce, manufacturing and maintenance. That does not mention the domestic or hobby users who also make such varied use of radio airways. Then there are radio navigation and radio location uses for the guidance of ships and aircraft on radio beams and radar and broadcasting uses such as television and sound These are now using satellite as well as earthbound methods. There are transmitters and translators relaying signals across the country into remote areas. We know all about this in Tasmania, especially with the introducheart on this tion of aggregation. We have learned that waves travel in straight lines in empty space, but things like the earth's surface and atmosphere, along with humidity, rainfall and solar activity, can do amazing things to change these signals. Our mountains in Tasmania seem to play great havoc with the new UHF signals. There are all these spaces to be used within the spectrum. And then there are our amateur users, those enthusiasts who have made a hobby out of communication and research around the world,who were the pioneers-going from the crystal sets and the morse code to the more sophisticated equipment that we install today. There are all those other uses, includ- sentations. ing radioastronomy; standard time and frequency signals; industrial, scientific and medical, and military and domestic uses. The latter area includes such things as microwave ovens and garage door openers. The purpose of these bills, therefore, is assist the implementation of a new apparatus licensing regime which resulted from a public inquiry by the Spectrum Management Agency some time ago. It is a chance for apparatus licensees to choose whether they pay their licence fees up-front or by annual instalment. The amendments are not related to the proposed increases to apparatus licence fees, including those for amateur radios. With all these things in modern day life, make things work better requires some sort of charging. The amateur radio users are one such group in that field. I have had a number of people write to me about the suggested amateur radio licence fee increase to $71. Their suggestion is that it is too much for an amateur group. I feel that there is a lot of merit in their argument. I have discussed this with members on my side of the House and I have put my concerns, as others have done, to the minister. These people do not operate for profit, and they play an important role in research, in emergency communication at times, and just as a communication tool between people who find it very difficult to enjoy physically travelling from place to place. This way they can travel on the radio airwaves. The gov.:rnment has responded to my representations and those of other members of the House on this matter. The SMA has decided to reduce the proposed fee, leading to a flat charge of $51 per annum for all amateurs. It was after consultation and in recognition of the valuable service provided by amateurs to the community in maintaining communication links and in training young people to be proficient in communications technology that the government took this decision, and I believe it was a good decision. I am told this will not be offset by any increase in fees paid by other radiocommunication licensees, so I am really happy that there has been a reasonable outcome to my repreIn general, these bills are essential to start coping with the mass use of the radio spectrum. I am sure that there will be a whole host of other uses as the years go by with the technological change we are facing. This will to require careful management and, if we are to make use of all our electronic equipment, we will need this sort of management. This is a way of keeping the costs of everything running smoothly and of ensuring it is shared among the users. I commend the bills to the House.

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is up directed to the Minister for Employment, up Education and Training. My question concerns the February employment data released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics today. What progress has been made in achieving the government's commitment to the creation of )

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Today' s labour force figures are indisputable evidence that the government's job strategy not only is on target but has well exceeded it. Today, with the figures that were released, we have smashed through the 500,000 jobs pledge that was made at the time of the last election. Do you remember the 500,000 target-,-the one that those opposite said we could not achieve? Not only have we exceeded it and taken it to close to 560,000, we have done it in two-thirds of the time. It did not take three years; it took two. What was also demonstrated in the labour force figures today was a significant increase in the participation rate, and that had the effect, as most members would be aware, of seeing only a smaller drop in the unemployment rate. It went from 9 per cent to 8.9 per cent. The female participation rate is now at its highest level ever recorded, and the total participation rate is almost at the record high level. This demonstrates that we are a government that was able not only to deliver the jobs but also to open up the opportunity to those jobs-to recognise that it is important not just to make jobs available but to expand the labour force at the same time. Our ability to expand the labour force takes away the inflationary pressure that would otherwise come from these very strong job growth figures. I might make, by way of observation, this point: if we had the participation rate that those on the other side left us with in 1983, do you know what the unemployment rate today would be? It would be 3.8 per cent. This is the sort of golden age of full employment that those on the other side want to hark back to in terms of reminding us of the Menzies era. The problem with the Menzies era was that it was full employment only for men. It was only men who were able to participate fully in the opportunities that provided. The Liberals had no strategy for opening up the opportunity for encouraging women, in particular, to enter the work force. In the last 12 months, 342,000 jobs have been created. Sixty-one per cent of them have gone to full-time jobs. I might say that those areas of particular disadvantage, the young people and the long-term unemployed in this country, have fared better in terms of the drop in the numbers of unemployed for their category.

Speaker: Mr MARTYN EVANS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Treasurer and it refers to the record high levels of employment announced today. Can the Treasurer advise the House how Australia's employment growth compares to that of other countries, and with employment growth in previous years?

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Bonython for his question. Certainly, I think the employment figures that have been announced today and referred to by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training in his earlier question are a tremendous outcome for the nation. A growth of 560,000 additional jobs in two years since the last election is a phenomenal performance-an absolutely phenomenal performance. And it is the envy,. I might say, of most other Western countries who could not remotely think of achieving that kind of outcome. This is an outcome which is phenomenal for Australia. I might say though that these seasonal adjustment factors do tend to produce some lumpy outcomes-we see spurts and we see a slowdown the next month; it is not an even progression. So just because we have this big spurt of 75,000 additional jobs in this month has not meant that we have changed our view about the employment outcome for this financial year. When I announced the mid-term review a little over a month ago, I said that we expected the employment outcome for this year to be a 3%per cent increase, up from three per cent in the budget. And today's figure does not really lead us to change that estimate but more or less confirms that we are growing very solidly indeed and that the budget estimates were too low. Other countries, as I have said, would that certainly look with envy on such growth in employment. If you look at the other OECD countries, you see, generally, rates of increase in employment which are far less than we are experiencing. For 1994, the OECD estimates that % for all of its member countries, the growth in employment will be 0.7 per cent0.7 per cent. This against a background where in our last 12 months, we have just chalked up 4.4 per cent, and for the whole year our estimate was 3% per cent. So we are growing around four per cent and Western countries generally are doing less than one per cent growth in employment. So, quite clearly, our performance on employment growth is extraordinarily good by comparison with other Western countries. Even for 1995 where it is generally expected that employment outcomes will be better in Western countries generally, the OECD estimate for that year at the moment is 1.3 per cent compared to our figures approaching four per cent. Quite clearly, w\e are doing extremely well on employment growth in comparison with other countries. But, Mr Speaker, if you look at the comparison with our past, you see also just how good that growth picture is. Since this government was elected just over 12 years ago, employment has increased by 1,865,000 additional jobs. That is an average growth in employment of 155,000 jobs a year. That compares with an average rate of growth of employment when the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer of this country, for the five years from 1977 up to 1982, of 52,000. That is 52,000 compared to our 155,000-approximately 100,000 less than we have achieved on average over the last 12 years. So you can clearly see, Mr Speaker, which party has the power to create employment. Quite clearly, it is the Labor Party which has been able to produce employment growth in this country, as against its predecessor government, which failed abysmally in that area when the now Leader of the Opposition was in charge of the Australian economy as Treasurer. If we look at the comments of the Leader of the Opposition recently, I think they are instructive in that context. Speaking on Adelaide radio station 5AA on 8 February this year, he said: The biggest obligation of any government, whether it is Mr Keating's government or the alternative government that we are offering, is to provide economic climate where people who are wiling to work and able to work can get jobs. Mr Speaker, if you look at that-the biggest obligation of government is to create employment-you can see who is more capable of producing satisfactory outcomes in respect of that biggest obligation. It is certainly not the opposition, or the Liberal Party. Mr Speaker, there is one other element of this employment growth which is very important for the House and for the people of Australia to understand, and that is that it is not just strong employment growth, it is strong employment growth in the context of low inflation. Of course, that is the absolute epitome of good government, to try to achieve strong employment growth in the context of low inflation. When we came into office we were looking at an inflation rate of 11.4 per cent-that was the inflation rate that the now Leader of the Opposition left us with when he was Treasurer-as well as an unemployment rate of 10 per cent. The average inflation rate when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer was 9.7 per cent. Under this government, the inflation rate has averaged, in our 12 years, 5.4 per cent, almost half of what it was under Mr Howard as Treasurer. We now have an inflation rate of 2.5 per cent-it has been 2.5 per cent or less for the last three years-in conjunction with these very high rates of employment growth. Mr Speaker, quite clearly, in terms of these fundamentals of good economic management-achieving strong employment growth, achieving low inflation-this government has been able to perform extremely creditably both by comparison with the past and by comparison with other countries. I know that the opposition does not like it. It says this employment growth is bad news. It wants to try to doom say as much as it can. But the reality is that this is unambiguously very good news for the Australian economy. Australian Broadcasting Corporation
