Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question and indicate to him and the House that I am aware of reports of approaches to industrial relations that involve the stripping away of the award safety net or, alternatively, allowing for conditions to be negotiated away. Under the government's Industrial Relations Reform Act, workers are guaranteed a comprehensive safety net, regardless of whether they are in existing employment or commencing a new job. In contrast, under the opposition's lobsback, we see guarantees only of four miserly conditions: annual leave, four weeks; two weeks non-cumulative sick leave; a minimum hourly rate of pay, not a weekly rate or an annual rate; and unpaid maternity leave. No-one is going to be fooled by that approach and the opposition's attempts to hide the consequences of its lobsback policy. Opting out offers new employees only those same four miserly conditions, those same four miserable provisions. lobsback does not so much as say what the minimum hourly rate will actually be. All the member for Flinders keeps saying is, 'That's a matter of detail. We'll get to it one day.' We are asking: just when are y.;e going to see that detail? When are we going to have revealed to the people of Australia what that minimum rate will be? If we look to the New Zealand system, which is a system the member for Flinders has waxed lyrical about and is on the public record and the record of this House on many occasions as praising, we see well illustrated the consequences of going down the lobsback path. We now have on the public record the analysis of Professor Harbridge of New Zealand's Victoria University, who has published an analysis of his country's Employment Contracts Act-that is, the EmployI ment Contracts Act for which you have been full of praise. That analysis shows that, under that system, women in New Zealand have fared far worse than men. Women have been the principal losers. They get lower wage increases; they have suffered even bigger reductions in overtime rates and in penalty rates than have men in comparable jobs in New Zealand. Members of the House will be interested to know that Professor Harbridge found that new workers in New Zealand are now being ty offered lower pay and conditions than existing employees. What that means is that in New Zealand you have a system of industrial apartheid.

Title: AND THE ARTS
text: I move: That this House censures the Minister for Communications and the Arts for: (1) making unfounded and false allegations that the Leader of the Opposition entered into a secret deal with Mr Kerry Packer to change Australia's media ownership laws; (2) wilfully and falsely asserting that a senior  Minister of the supposed deal asserting he knew the identity of that person and the substance of his claims; (3) attempting to aid and abet the deceit of the Prime Minister on the subject by repeating baseless claims of the Prime Minister which he knew to be false; Orders (4) failing to detail any evidence in support of the alleged conspiracy to this House and attempting to mislead it into believing the falsehood; (5) refusing to apologise to the Leader of the Opposition and the House for his smears and misconduct; (6) failing to competently discharge his duties as a Minister of the Crown and a Member of this House. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has never been the same since Mr Kerry Packer went on television and made certain statements. Mr Packer was asked about the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and he said: He's been around for a long time. I think he's a decent man. I think he's an honest man and I think he's a man who has seen the mistakes made and I don't think he will make them again. That was an objective statement of an observ in that statement was what the rest of Australia already knew; that the Leader of the Opposition is a decent man and that the Leader of the Opposition is an honest man. But that duties as statement of what the whole of Australia knew drew the Prime Minister into a fury. The Prime Minister came back and made a statement that no-one else in Australia knew. He made an allegation that he knew something the rest of Australia did not. He alleged, in a calculated, specific, dishon- wonder est and deceitful allegation, that this statement own was made because a secret deal existed between the Leader of the Opposition and Mr Packer. It was a calculated, specific, dishonest and deceitful allegation. The Prime Minister, after failing to detail his allegations to House, after having the opportunity to into this House and submit himself to tioning, hopped on a jet and hotfooted it to Singapore. It was no accident that in Singapore he returned to the theme. As Laurie Oakes reports in this week's Bulletin, there he was, down the back of the plane, trying to incite the journalists to write this up. There '. was, down the back of the plane, engaging 'smear, innuendo, falsehood and lies. He knew that it was false. He knew that he could substantiate it. He had, cowardly, not come into this House and made the allegations; went down the back of the plane and tried seed them in the journalists' minds. Mr Keating claimed to those journalists, as reported by Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin: ... he:s told the Packer camp and the Packer camp have told me. That was the allegation. He was not trying base it, as the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) now is, on statements that were in the public domain. It was not enough for Mr Keating to say that the Leader of the Opposition had a genuine view about cross-media ownership. It was not enough debate the merits, as you are now trying do, little Sir Echo; be careful. He had to allege a conspiracy and he had to allege first-hand witness to that conspiracy. Little Sir Echo did not take long to take the chant: 'War is peace; black is white; Prime Minister is always right.' But the trouble was that the Prime Minister was in different time zone. So as the chant came from the Prime Minister and was echoed back in Australia, it became increasingly out of date. 1 wonder how he felt, after he said that, yes, there was a senior executive in the Packer camp who had given this information to the Prime Minister, when he woke up on Wednesday, 8 March, 1995 and read the headline on the front page of the Australian: 'Richardson denies Packer, Howard deal'. 1 how he felt when the godfather of his faction, former senator Graham Richardson, walked away from him? 1 wonder how he felt when Peter Barron, the great strategist of the Labor Party, walked away from him? 1 wonder how he felt when the senior execthis utives denied the substance of this claim? 1  questhe substance of the claim? 1 know how he over felt when the Leader of the Opposition denied the substance of the claim: he felt caught, and he was.  he the Leader of the Opposition is a liar, Mr in Barron is a liar, former senator Graham Richardson is a liar, and the only person who not tells the truth is Paul Keating. That is the  he the Leader of the Opposition is a liar; Mr to Barron is a liar; former senator Graham Richardson is a liar; and the only person who tells the truth is the Prime Minister. Well, who would want to be in a situation like that? And he knows it is false. He knows this was a smear which he himself walked into. If 1 were the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), to 1 would be briefing him overtime right now. Send him back; make sure that you give him all the lines. People sometimes have to realise in life that they are not up to it, and this minister is one such person. It should be remembered that before he was appointed to to the position of minister for communications to he had that moment of self-realisation. He said, 'I don't know that I'm up to it.' He said, a 'I don't know that I'm up to making tough decisions.' He said, 'I'm not sure I have up demonstrated yet that I'm good enough to be the a minister handling difficult issues.' Let me tell you, old son: we're sure. We're absolutely a sure that you have not demonstrated that you are a minister that can handle difficult issues. I made some inquiries of the Labor Party. Title: AND THE ARTS
text: The tragic thing is that the only thing he wanted to be when he grew up was a fireman, but Paul Keating made him minister for communications. That is the tragic thing. After all of the damage that you have done and all of the damage that you have attempted to do to the Leader of the Opposition, there is an opportunity for you to show your mettle. There is an opportunity for you to come in here and prove that you are up to ministerial office. There is an opportunity for you to show that you can be a minister. Sure, you may never be more than a mediocre, middle-of-the-road minister, but you could get there if you admitted the truth. All you have to say is, 'There was no deal.' Each one of your statements has made it clear that you have no evidence. All you have to do is say, 'I did not have the evidence.' All you have to do is say, 'I have no information.' All you have to do is say, 'I dug myself in because I was trying to defend the Prime Minister in relation to an unfounded allegation, and I apologise.' All you have to do is say, 'I will from now on make my own judgments, be my own minister, be my own man and deal with policy.' But, if you fail to do that, if even at this late hour you cannot do that, then the facts are clear: you cannot be trusted with a sensitive portfolio. You cannot be trusted to deal with the precise evidence that is required in that position. You cannot be trusted to deal with the nuances, fineness and technicalities of that portfolio and you are not up to the job of minister for communications. That is the tragedy for Australia. MICHAEL LEE: Absolutely. Do not stand up here and say' A petition was signed in 1991' or 'Something was said in the paper last week' or 'Ray Martin said on A Current Affair last night' - you made a highly specific allegation. Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: Your allegation was that there was a deal, because it was not enough for you and it was not enough for the Prime Minister to actually debate this issue on its merits. I will tell you why: it would not have explained the Packer statement. The Packer statement was what started the whole thing. The Prime Minister had to have, for his own conscience, some explanation as to how an independent businessman in this country would come to the conclusion that the Leader of the Opposition was honest-a conclusion that most of Australia has come to. It was not enough to talk about the need to change cross-media ownership rules. You made a specific allegation. It is an allegation that you are now walking away from. The fact is that we know it is false and you know it is false. That is why you will not repeat it. How many times have we asked you to get up here and repeat it? You will have 20 minutes shortly. All I want to hear from you is this: the Prime Minister was told by a senior executive who holds the position of? His name is? On such and such a date he told the Prime Minister that the deal was? That media ownership laws would be changed in return for? That is all you have to say. If you fail to do that, you are effectively walking away from yourself. That is the reality. Why do we believe this is important? I will to tell you why we believe this is important. We are sick of a Prime Minister who engages in smear and lie. We are sick of a Prime Minister who comes up with outrageous allegations, puts them out into the public domain, lets the smear stick, and before he can ever be harnessed with the truth moves on to the next one. It is the age old trick. You cannot catch up with the last smear because he is already on to the next one, and by the time you try to nail that one he has gone on to the one after that. Do you remember the performance that started all of this off on the Channel 9 program? I can remember it very well. I was mowing my lawn one Saturday afternoon when my wife said, ' Mr Laurie Oakes is on the phone.' I got on the phone and Mr Oakes said, 'I have just had a request from the Prime Minister who wants to knock you off the Sunday program tomorrow because he has got something big to announce.' The Prime Minister went on the Sunday program. Do you know what he announced? He made an announcement not in relation to the Leader of the Opposition, the state of the economy, the current account deficit, rising interest rates, the plight of home buyers or the gap between the rich and the poor. None of those things were on his mind. The only thing that was on his mind was this intense hatred that he has when people disagree with him. But it is more than that. This is not just about Kerry Packer; this is a determined effort by the Prime Minister to send a message to the businesses of Australia that anybody who dares to criticise him can expect government retribution. That is the bottom line of this campaign. If you are a big businessman like Kerry Packer you might be able to look after yourself, but if you are not, 'if you dare to stand up, if you dare to make some honest comments, if you dare to say 'The emperor has no clothes', he says, 'I will turn the full forces of my lie machine back on to you.' That is the bottom line of this campaign. That is the campaign of the merchant of venom who, for 12 years, has been practising smear, innuendo and lie. This has been the successive campaign over years. On that program, he made one of the most unbelievable allegations you have ever heard in your life: Mr Kerry Packer was engaged in a scam in which Murray Farquhar attempted to take gold bars from the Philippines national  Farquhar. It was not even the worse scam of Murray Farquhar. That might have been a bad scam of Murray Farquhar, but he was involved in one which was much worse. You know what it was too. Murray Farquhar's greatest scam was not trying to take gold bars out of the Philippines; Murray Farquhar's greatest scam was in August 1975 discharging one Laurie Brereton on bribery and conspiraable cy charges. That was his greatest scam. I can boast imagine Laurie Brereton when he over bribery charges on the Botany council and they said to him, 'Murray's got the case. Wasn't that a lucky deal?' Murray Farquhar got the case, and that was the outcome in 1975. But what did that have to do with media ownership laws? You tell me. What was the substance of that allegation? It came back, you knew it would, to this persistent camThe paign. We are seeing it in relation to Packer. We saw it in relation to Du Pont when it was reported on the front Australian Financial Review. We have seen it from other employer groups. We saw it in relation to the HIA. We saw it in relationto the ACC!. This is a concerted blacken the name of anybody who dares stand up to the Prime Minister and his pretencations sions. The tragedy for you is that you have been caught up in the wake of this, little Echo. The tragedy for you is that you have become part of this web of deceit. The tragyou edy for you is that, without adult supervision, you have been pulled in. As I said in the House the other day, is it that the Prime Minister always accuses others of conspiring against him? Why is it that there is always a deal going on? I will tell you why: because this Prime Minister always accuses others of the standard of behaviour that he has himself. He could not conceive of the possibility that anybody could ever say a nice thing about a politician without having some quid pro quo. Why is that? Because nobody could say anything nice about the Prime Minister without some kind of quid pro quo. If we are talking about cross-media laws, you might actually deal with the allegations that are made in the Shawcross book. It was the Prime Minister who made the cross-media laws. It was the Prime Minister who just happened to deliver laws that created the same situation as Alan Ramsey reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 8 March 1995. Alan Ramsey states: And nobody was more single-minded in never offending either media baron than was the HonourMember for Blaxland. Keating would often in private it was he who "made Kerry his first billion" by his architecture of Labor's cross-media came. up rules in the mid-1980s ... Now we find that these cross-media rules are somehow designed to make sure that you do not get too much wealth or power or money. The fact was that they were orchestrated for the reverse. The fact was that the Prime Minister was the architect. The fact is that the Prime Minister made unfounded allegations. as The fact is that you were caught up in them. fact is that you are part of them. The fact Mr is that you ought to be censured by this House for your disgraceful smear and unpage of the founded allegations.

It is not a question of whether the government's media policy is good or our media policy is bad or ought to be changed. It has absolutely nothing at all do with that. This started by the Prime Minister lying through his teeth by saying that I had made  to provide evidence. Evidence is, as you know, material which supports the allegation. The allegation was that I had made a secret deal. Yet, for all the words that have been uttered, for all the huffing and puffing that has occurred today, you have produced not one skerrick of evidence. Michael, you know deep down in your heart that you have been caught out on this. You have been serving the Prime Minister. You have been slavishly backing up the Prime Minister like the faithful little boy Sir Echo you really are to the Prime Minister. You know deep down that you have not made one skerrick of a case against me. You can talk about media policy and you can, as you inevitably will, use your weight of numbers to pass this motion today. The more censure motions you pass, the more I recognise the political threat that I pose to your leader. I keep picking up the paper of a morning and seeing stories written out of Singapore and Germany saying, 'Really it's a long-term strategy.' It is so clever. You start off by making a false allegation, you go quiet for a week, then you go overseas and you revive the allegation. You hijack a press conference with the Prime Minister of Singapore, insulting one of our Asian neighbours by doing so, then you go off to Germany and say, 'This is terrible. This should be talked about back in Australia.' What is the explanation for this? You go down to the back of the plane and say, 'Really it is a long-term strategy to ensnare Howard.' It is so subtle, it is so sophisticated. But instead of it ensnaring Howard, it has ensnared Lee, because was he was not told that the script had changed. It is so secret, sophisticated and convoluted that the only people who really understand it are the Prime Minister and his minders who put it together. It passes strange that we in this House to should have lectures about media policy from people who speak on behalf of the Prime Minister. If media policy in Australia is an unmitigated mess in 1995, it is the fault of one person more than anybody else: the Prime Minister of Australia. The Prime Minister of Australia is the proud author of the policy known as 'You have to be either queen of the screen or prince of print'. The real code language is not that you have to be one thing or the other but that when the policy was devised it was devised with one sole objective in mind: to undermine, even destroy, the old Fairfax media empire and the Herald and Weekly Times empire. No person bears a greater responsibility for the high level of foreign ownership of the Australian media, and any existing levels of concentration of Australian media, than Paul Keating. Paul Keating has done more to hand the media of this country over to foreigners and has done more to concentrate media ownership than any politician left standing in Australia. The last person who ought to have the nerve to raise media policy in this parliament is somebody who seeks to speak on behalf of the Prime Minister of Australia. It was the Prime Minister of Australia who told the former editorial manager, Max Suich, of the Fairfax media empire in the late 1980s how much he hated the Fairfax newspapers and how much he was bent on destroying them. We all remember that very accurate report of a cabinet meeting in the mid-1980s when the then Prime Minister of Australia, Bob Hawke, supported by the now Prime Minister, Paul Keating, was trying to get the media laws of this country changed. Nobody could quite understand what their end game was because there seemed to be no rhyme or reason or logic in what they were trying to do. Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY

text: Certainly. I will be happy to do it. The amendment now reads: That all words after "That" be deleted and the following words be inserted: "This House censures the Leader of the Opposition for his reversal of his media policy against media concentration and its refusal to state its po licy towards the current threats to the cross-media ownership rules. The House further notes that the Opposition confusion on this matter comes against a background of the Government's success in achieving record job growth. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) rorts the issue in any way, and that gives me the opportunity to do that. Mr Costello-- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Before the Leader of the House commences, should he not indicate to you which of the words have been struck out and where the amendment will end?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: When the Leader of the Opposition spoke in this debate, he discussed cross-media ownership rules, foreign ownership rules and media policy generally. Throughout his speech, he failed to refer to not only current opposition policies but past opposition policies. After hearing the Leader of the Opposition debate the issues that surrounded the decisions last decade--changes to the ownership rules to separate ownership of the electronic media from ownership of the print media-a reasonable person would think that his remarks indicate that the opposition stood in diametrical opposition to us on those particular propositions. They supported us. They supported us on changes we put in place at the time. They merely said that they had some vague concerns about them, but their concerns did not go to the opportunity to establish a network in television-which was the basic element of the electronic media one, apart from the cross-media ownership rules at the time. They did not oppose that proposition. In so far as they had any difficulties with it at all, they had difficulties with whether or not you could move from owning one or two stations in major metropolitan centres around the country to owning any number of them. Then they had doubts as to whether you ought to be excluded from the print media in those centres at the same time. That was the area of their doubt. So, if you listened to the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition, you would think that he stood here as a devotee of diversity. You would think that the government had somehow failed in its task to ensure diversity, and that that was the reason the governmentamong others-should be censured for its long standing media policies in this area. That happens not to be true. The only thing consistent about the Leader of the Opposition when it comes to these matters is his vagueness. He has been vague when he was taken to task by the press on what his policies now happen to be. He was vague then. The media release he re-released earlier this week is such a typical box opposition presentation on media policy that it is worth recounting. The style of presentation has not changed over the years. The basic thrust is, 'For God's sake, do not force us to commit ourselves in any detailed fashion on anything related to media policy. Please let us stand around the place, shouting out that the government's policy is a mess but, for God's sake, do not tie us down.' The Leader of the Opposition said: The opposition sees merit in the Government's proposal to removing the existing two-station rule. At this stage, we are disposed to support the Government's proposal and that any television network should have the right to reach 75 per cent of the viewing audience. However we should be looking carefully at the report of the Senate Select Committee, established at the initiative of the Opposition, as we are particularly keen to ensure that the introduction of the 75 per cent rule does not unfairly disadvantage regional television stations. The Opposition also believes that as part and parcel of the removal of the two-station rule and the introduction of the 75 per cent principle there should be a removal of the existing barriers to entry into both television and radio. This is those opposite supporting the ability to set up a television network in this country. But where did they have a problem with it? They came to a problem on this point: On the question of cross-media ownership we are not convinced that the prohibitions proposed by the Government are either necessary or can be justified. So the official position of the opposition was at that stage: you could have a network and you could own newspapers in all· the areas where you had that network. He hates a reference to history when it is a reference to history that deals with himself. He loves a reference to history when he thinks it makes a point about the Prime Minister (Mr point K,eating) .. That is the first point that you would make about the Leader of the Opposition. Then he said: The Government's policies encourage foreign ownership. There is an interesting fact in the 1991 document-which I will get to a bit later-about a petition he signed adopting a policy that he said he had never espoused. That petition, even though it was a matter of debate at time, contains no reference to foreign ownership. There is a specific reason why it contains no mention of foreign ownership. That was that whilst there was a substantial amount of bipartisan unity, I have to say, having been on the receiving end of a lobbying about it as a minister in the portfolio at the time, on further. defending the cross-media ownership rules that they previously opposed, there was no bipartisanship on the subject of foreign ownership. Why was there no bipartisanship on the subject offoreign ownership? For this reason: the government was supportive of putting limitations on it; the opposition was not. Whatever level of foreign ownership has been achieved, and whether or not you regard that level of foreign ownership as suitable or contrary to the national interest, if the opposilogic tion had had policy control at that point in time, it would have been greater. This is the style of argument of the person who wants to be regarded as a man of great integrity in this place, the Leader of the flopped. Opposition. You make an accusation about government, you attack it from both the left and· the right and you hope to God nobody reviews your history. If he does review your history, you get up around the gallery and inform them of what it is that you think that they are up to, trying to obfuscate the defence of themselves or whatever by the propositions they put. He is being very free in this debate and out in the public forum with his accusations of lying. He has, nevertheless, produced a statement at the beginning of this week which was an out and out lie. That was actually picked up, funnily enoughMr Tim Fischer- Mr Speaker, I rise on a of order. You, Mr Speaker, have previously ruled in this area where the accusation . of lie and lying has been made. I submit to you on balance that this one falls on the other side of the ledger and should be dealt with accordingly.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: Order! I also said during the debate today that I would hope that both sides in this debate would reflect upon what is unparliamentary language. But I do recall the on a number of occasions the Leader of the Opposition using that terminology in the way which it has been used.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: I will not use it again, Mr Speaker, which was not a requirement placed upon the Leader of the Opposition. I just use it that once and now illustrate the point It was a very interesting interview the other night on Ray Martin's show. In the same way as he should not have entered this debate, he ought not to have gone on Ray Martin's show last night, because Ray Martin, who is a good interviewer, had the integrity to go through with him his 1991 position as opposed to his 1987 position, which was about as vague as you could have put it but did actually emerge at the end of the day as being one of opposition to cross-media ownership rules. So we will give him what he said as back in 1987, even though by very tortuous he finally arrived at opposition to the ownership rules. Nevertheless, in 1991 he was absolutely clear cut. The transcript states: Martin: Now what about the suggestion today in Parliament by Kim Beazley that you've flipThat in fact you were a party to a petition the in 1991 that called for tougher rules? Howard: Well, that was the Opposition's policy at that particular timeeven though he had said privately and publicly that he had been devoted to a looser crossmedia ownership ruleMartin: But you signed that petition? Howard: Well, I wasn't the Leader of the Opposition then, and I wasn't the spokesman on communications and I went along as a team player, I went along with the Opposition's situation. It is all right to sling around accusations about the Prime Minister, that he is a man without integrity and tells lies. But we now know the criteria by which John Howard is prepared to mislead the public as to his point of view. He will be prepared to mislead the public as to his point of view when he is not the spokesman on communications; when he is not the Leader of the Opposition; when he is a team player; and when he goes along with the opposition situation. We now know the price tag that is placed by the Leader of the Opposition on his personal integrity as far as that is concerned. I would say it is a pretty diverse caveat on the requirement for him to tell the truth. One thing that is consistent about the opposition position is the slipping and the sliding. There has been a slipping and a sliding on this. The Leader of the Opposition says, 'Oh, no, I do not have any particular deal in this situation. I go along and have a couple of chats. In the course of those couple of chats I reveal that I have informed Mr Packer that my position privately and publicly is that which it was back in 1987.' Smarm, smarm. He says, 'It is no problem as far as I am concerned. I don't agree with the prince of print and the queen of screen and all the rest of it. I never have, except when he bid last time as part of the Tourang consortium in 1991 for Fairfax. Then I was opposed to it. So I do have something to explain. I just want to give you my assurance, Sir, that that little dereliction on my part was due to the fact that I wasn't Leader of the Opposition at the time; I was not the spokesman on communications. I went along as a team player. I went along with the opposition's situation. So please ignore that, Sir, and remember that back in 1987 I would have given you the lot. But please don't support me. Please don't get out there on your channels and say anything nice about me. No, please don't do that; just be absolutely clear that I have crawfished away from that terrible position that I took on the Tourang bid. I beg your forgiveness. We don't have any conspiracy going, do we? There is no special pleading here.' What a gutless, snivelling, crawling performance that is. Then he has a little difficulty because somebody wants to ask him to sharpen up in his policy area and to say something a bit straightforward about all this. So he is finally brought down. When asked, 'Tell us what you would do. You sort of said you were with him back in 1987,' he said: I am very strongly in favour of diversity and it's worth saying that the man who's done more to concentrate foreign ownership and single proprietor ownership, of the Australian media is Paul Keating. Another question: But do you think it is undesirable? Mr Howard replied: I think it's undesirable to have too heavier concentration in anything, whether it's newspapers, television or the lot, but I don't think it's desirable to personalise it, I think you have to have rules and principles. He was then asked: But do you think there should be a rule, do you agree that there should be some sort of rule to avoid the ownership of a major newspaper in a city and one of the major television networks? He replied: I think there should be a rule to prevent too much concentration of ownership and the question of whether you best do it by a specific rule or whether you do it in some other way was the essence of what I said back in 1987. Absolute bulldust! He was asked: But what I'm trying to get at, is to which Mr Howard said: I know what you're trying to get at, and I've given you my answer. He was asked: ... undesirable circumstance? The answer was: I think it is desirable to have as much diversity as possible. In answer to another question, he stated: WelI'it would depend on the size of the market and how you define the market. Well, fair dinkum: you are a very lucky man. The press has let you lot off the hook on this one during this week. When it comes to a particular policy debate, you have been jumping up and down on both sides of this issue, desperately trying to arrive at a conclusion, but with one underlying theme: 'We shall bow at the altar of whoever it is who might provide us with a useful level of political support. If those folk are around, we will apologise for past attitudes that we have taken on this matter which may have had cause to give grievous offence. And if those past attitudes are pointed out to us in a way that makes us look like we are a pack of liars, without integrity, as we slither into our hollows on this one, we will explain it by the fact that we had no official responsibilities at the time and we were just going along with the mob.' The Leader of the Opposition, at the end of the day, never learns. He has spent a lifetime going along with the mob and he does not deserve the attention of this parliament on this matter. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: Whilst the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has developed a well known routine in his presentation, it was one of the most pathetic presentations I have heard from him for a long time, because the challenge for him was a very simple challenge, and that was to produce some evidence to back up the claim. He started by making a point about how many times they had censured the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), which was pathetic in itself. That was his opening point. He then got the amendment wrong and had to change tack on that. He then ran out of time. He filled his 15 minutes with nothing but bluster. It really demonstrates the case which is the censure motion against the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee). I say to the Minister for Communications and the Arts: if we look at his ashen faced complexion, you know, and we know that you know, there was no deal. The minister and I were sworn in together in this place in early 1985. I have been watching him for some time. I suppose it is fair to say that his the Labor Party has been largely uninterrupted. The Labor Party has been in office and he has been able to ride in on the coat-tails of others to assume now the high office of minister for communications. In the last 10 years I think there are a couple of lessons that he ought to have learnt about politics. The first thing is that a lot of people think that politics is a game. It is true that politics has many of the characteristics of a game. It has the rough and tumble of a game. It has the theatre of a game. From time to time you have the professional free kick taken by one side, whilst breaking the rules, to still give their side a benefit. That is accepted when you are playing a game. But the fact is that this is not a game. Yes, it has the characteristics of a game but politics is no game. I think that when we look into your face, minister, you realise that simple fact. When you set out deliberately, maliciously and without justification to smear, when you set out to conspire with othersand, in particular, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)-to attack the reputation of another and impugn the integrity of a member of this House, doing so in a baseless and malicious way, you damage your own reputation. The Leader of the Opposition is not damaged by this; you are the one who is damaged by this. Sure, you are going to use your numbers and knock off our censure motion. You will put through your silly amendment. But the reality is, minister, that this damage is damage that you will incur. . I understand why. You owe your place in political life to the Prime Minister. He is your promoter. Just as he knelt at the knee of Jack Lang and learned the tricks of the trade of the New South Wales Right, you sit on the knee of the Prime Minister and learn the lessons of politics from him. As you consider your political career, you think that you owe him; but I would say to you, minister-and this is the second lesson for you-that you are a young bloke compared with the Prime Minister. In fact, the Prime Minister has been here a long time. I do not think he will·be here that much longer. You are 37 years old, you are a very young fellow-in fact, you are rise in very young by your actions as well. The reality is that your reputation will ultimately be built not on the fact that you have been able to hang onto the skirts of the Prime Minister but on the basis of your actions in this place. You might think that your reputation is one that is built only on what your colleagues think of you, but you are wrong. Ultimately, if you are going to have a reputation in this place, it will be a reputation that rests on the opinions of everybody in this House--even people on our side of this House. We will not forget this malicious, nasty, little smear campaign that you have been running and, ultimately, your reputation will be based on what sort of person you are. I heard the Prime Minister say the other day-and it is a classic Keating quote-'If I were Howard, I'd have had a plan that would drive me mad.' The way the Prime Minister is going on, we do not need a plan because he is pretty mad already-absolutely mad. He will not be here much longer, minister. So you will have to stand on your own two feet and build your own reputation. You work on the basis of the philosophy you have learnt from the New South Wales Right, which is: say anything and do anything. It is a sort of 'whatever it takes' philosophy. The reality is that, if you do not do the right thing-if you do not stand up today as you have been provided the opportunity to do-and admit the error of your ways, then this reputation about you will stick. I suppose that, in your imagination, you may think that you are the next Paul Keating, and Richo told you that you had those prospects. But I have got news for you. You are not the next Paul Keating, mate; you are the next Ros Kelly, the whiteboard lady. They say you are the rising star. The last we had around this place was the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths). What we found out about the member for Maribyrnong was that he could not even run a sandwich shop. That is your destiny, if this is the standard which you are going to set. I just say, by way of an aside, that we have not seen the Codd report on the member for Maribyrnong. It is about time it was produced. Before I set out the case against you, which is an open and shut case if ever I saw one, let me just deal very briefly-it will not take long to deal with because not much was said by you people-with the basis of yourresponse. Your response simply is one based on an argument about coalition policy. You build your case, not on secret deals, but on all our public statements. It is bizarre in that you guys start with a proposition that there is a secret deal but, when we put the heat on you for the evidence, your evidence consists of the public commentS of the Leader of the Opposition. I will come back to the comments you made on Monday night in a minute. It was interesting to hear that your defence today was based on the Leader of the Opposition's remarks last night on television. Perhaps it is a good tryon your part, but the reality is that the charge against you is that you set out maliciously to smear the Leader of the Opposition. That is the charge you have got to answer, and you have dismally failed to do so. If it were simply a matter of a disagreement about coalition policy, then I would remind you that, on that basis, we would be mounting a similar argument against Mr Keating. Mr Keating himself has said that really he questions the ongoing relevance of the cross-media ownership because of the way in which technology is changing. I reckon that allegation would have a hell of a lot more credit if it came from us. Do you know why? Because if anybody has ever done deals in this country, it is you blokes, not us. It is amazing. You go all the way back to 1987 and get stuck into John Howard, but the fact is that, if you go back to what John Howard said in 1987 on the public record, Kerry Packer was backing you guys, not us-and rising star that said so pUblicly. We come to this with clean hands. This whole thing started off with one simple statement - with Kerry Packer expressing the views that most Australians have-that is, that John Howard is a pretty decent, honest bloke and he is not a bad alternative Prime Minister. Sure, in your eyes this is a political crime of absolutely huge dimensions. The thought that this is an idea that is going to sweep the country absolutely sends shivers up your spine.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: It does. It drives them mad. It drives them troppo, as Senator Alston said. But that is the reality of it, and that is where this whole thing started. Let me just go to what you said so we can come to the charge that we have against you. What you said on Monday night, Minister, was a pretty clear statement. This is what you said: I along with a number of other people are certainly aware of information which we believe links Howard to the allegations which the Prime Minister has put forward. You furthermore said: Ah, well, I think that the claim that the evidence only circumstantial is based on a claimed ledge as to who might have passed on the tion to the Prime Minister. If the person who passed on the information to the Prime Minister was in a position to know, then I think it's pretty firm evidence. Then Lyndall Curtis asked: And you believe they were in a position to know? Your answer: Absolutely. That is a pretty clear statement. That is clear statement that you had evidence as to whom, as to when and as to the detail. The reality is that you have not. The whole week, Minister, we have provided you with opportions. tunities. We have asked you the what of this allegation; we have asked you the when of this allegation; and we have asked you the do so. who of this allegation-who was it that provided the information? At every opportunisured. ty, you have walked away from the question. You did not even have the guts to front up to question time yesterday. You were up there watching Sesame Street and having afternoon tea. We had a division after question time and, 10 and behold, here you were. You have failed to respond to this charge on every occasion it has been brought up. Let us put the whole thing in context. What do we have here? We have nothing whatsoever other than a political campaign Minister, you have been brought up in a school of politics which thinks it is smart to run a smear campaign. You think that this the way in which good public policy is Minister's conducted. The reality is that it ain't. It serious allegation. You work on the basis that mud sticks. Well, this is mud that ain't going to stick, Minister. This is a campaign we intend to and do repel. You, of course, act in conjunction with the Prime Minister, and he is a master of the smear campaign. You think that you can profit by it, but if you look at it you will see that what we have is a situation where the Prime Minister attempts to hold on to his Mr office by the use of a smear campaign. In doing so, he demeans the office of Prime Minister. It is no wonder that there is a cynicism about Australian politics that has is developed in the last 10 years when people knowlike you and the Prime Minister act in the informaway you do---in a malevolent way. Minister, you have two simple choices. Your first choice is to substantiate your claim. We have given you repeated opportunities to do so. Instead, you and Mr Keating have repeated the claim. Your second choice is to salvage some credibility for what you have had to say. That would be to stand here and to admit that you have no evidence and to a very apologise, not only to the Leader of the Opposition but to the House generally, for the fact that you have waged a campaign for a week now on baseless, unsubstantiated allegaMinister, I say to you that a glimpse of decency, a whiff of honesty, might give you that chance to salvage. I do not expect you to The reality is that you deserve to be cenWhy do you deserve to be censured? You deserve to be censured because you lied. It is as simple as that. You have lied to this House, and you have lied to the Australian people. I think you also deserve to be censured because you have slavishly repeated the lies of others, and you have done so knowingly. There has never been any doubt in your mind, has there, Minister? Let us face it. There has never been any doubt in your mind that this whole thing was a malion your part. cious smear campaign. Lastly, Minister, you deserve censure not just for the fact that you lied, not just for the is fact that you slavishly repeated the Prime lies but for your political incompeis a tence in putting your own reputation in the hands of somebody like Keating. That is what you have done: you have put your own reputation in the hands of someone like Keating. And, I tell you, he won't be grateful, Minister. The fact is, he is off on one of his Europeanjaunts. He is off there in Berlin about to enjoy the sights. I think as we rise and go home to our electorates, it is 11 a.m. and an early start for the Prime Minister, who will off doing the sights of Berlin with the Mayor of Berlin, offering and pressing home his own ideas for improvements to the Berlin streetscape. That is a pretty busy day for him because then after that he will have 4Y2 hours of rest in which to prepare himself for. the gruelling main event of the day, dinner at the Schloss Charlottenberg hosted by the same unfortunate mayor who can look forward to his lecturing on Berlin streetscapes during the day. Whilst he is doing that, Minister, you will be reading the comment pieces that state that basically, you are a liar; you do not tell the truth; you are justa little Sir Echo in a malicious, grubby campaign to impugn the reputation of someone who has worked hard and, with justification, has a good reputation in this place. You deserve censure. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: There was one simple way for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to resolve this matter. He had 20 minutes to do it. All he had to do was deny the allegation  he failed and refused to do so. We know why-because he has done the deal. We did not need his silence today. The case was proved conclusively yesterday and today by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) and again today by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). If we did not need his silence today then we certainly got it last night on A Current Affair, Kerry's program on Kerry's station. It is very pertinent to read the transcript back into the record. Let us see what the Leader of the Opposition had to say last night in his interview with Ray Martin: MARTIN: How many times would you have   briefly on the phone, a couple of weeks after I became Leader of the Opposition, and I had one meeting with him subsequently to that, and the question of the Opposition's media policy was not raised at that discussion. No talk, of course, about how many conversations he mayor may not have had with him before he became Leader of the Opposition; be but I will leave that to one side-we know what Senator Alston said in respect of that matter. Mr Martin goes on with a subsequent question: Now what about the suggestion today in Parliament by Kim Beazley that you flip-flopped. That in fact you were a party to a petition in 1991 that called for tougher rules? HOWARD: Well that was the Opposition's policy at that particular time. MARTIN: But you signed that petition? HOWARD: Well, I wasn't the Leader of the Opposition then, and I wasn't the spokesman on communications and I went along as a team player, I went along with the Opposition's situation. MARTIN: But that's a petition again-October24, 1991. And this very revealing interview goes on: MARTIN: Well, let's shoot straight it would have been nice if we had had a straight answer last night from the Leader of the Opposition. And he could have solved all this today by giving a straight answer in the course of this debateShould Kerry Packer be allowed to own Channel 9 and the Fairfax group? HOWARD: Well, I don't think you should deal with these things-no pun intended-on the basis of personalities. We know why he does not want to deal with it on the basis of personalities. We know why he does not want to deal with it on the basis of the cross-media ownership rules. We know why he does not want to deal with it on the basis of the policies. Because we know he has done a deal with the personality-that is why. Mr Martin goes on to say: Should any man then? Let's forget personalities. Any man or woman should they own a television network in Australia and also the major publishing group? This is a very perceptive question from Mr Martin-it goes right to the heart of the policy. It continues: HOWARD: Well, it depends entirely on what the other players in all of the media markets are. It depends on a whole range offactors. I'm not going to say yes or no to that question. Why should I? That is the precise question to which he should say yes or no because that goes right to the heart of media policy. And he won't say yes or no because we know he has not put his mind to the policy-he has done a deal with the personality. All the Leader of the Opposition had to do today was to come into this House and say, 'We've all had allegations made against us before. I deny it. It's not true.' He did not say it, he would not say it, he cannot say it because he has done a deal-a deal that bears no relationship to policy, a deal that bears no relationship to public interest, a deal that bears no relationship to the best way of managing media policy in this country.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It goes to the relevance of this debate. An allegation has just been made about a deal. The member for Perth has another 10 minutes in which to identify the people with whom the deal was done or he insults them as well.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: Mr Jenkins)Order! The member for O'Connor was cautioned earlier today.

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: As I said at the outset: in any event, the case was proved conclusively yesterday and today by the Minister for Communications and the Arts and by the Leader of the House. And it was proved by the words of the Leader of the Opposition on the Ray Martin show last night. What do you have to do in this place to get a debate on the economy? When will those opposite come into this House and debate the economy? Today, as a result of the good graces of the Speaker, I got an MPI on the economy, on the employment figures. Those opposite ran away from that. They had to come up with this stunt. Last week I also put in an MPI on the economy and they put in one on sport. We then saw the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) parading as a sportsman for the first time in his life. What do you have to do? I was very pleased to see the amendment moved by the Leader of the House, such that we are now also deliberating this motion: That the House further notes the opposition's confusion on this matter comes against a background of the government's success in achieving record job growth. That is what those opposite do not want to talk about. They do not want to talk about the government's success in achieving record job growth. They do not want to talk about it because they hate it. In the 1980s, their leader said, 'The times will suit me.' He wanted the times to suit him. He wanted to have political success over the hardship of the Australian public. The times did not suit him then and they will not suit him now. Today, with the release of the February figures, we have seen record high levels of employment. More Australians are in employment today than ever before-over 560,000 new jobs since April 1993. After two years, the government has more than met the commitment it made in March 1993 for 500,000 new jobs in the course of this term. I remind the House what the previous opposition speaker, the member for Flinders (Mr Reith}-the then shadow Treasurer-had to say about that election promise. I quote from The Australian of 22 February 1993: The Opposition spokesman on Treasury matters,  Labor would be treading water on employment. 'It's a major embarrassment for the Government which shows that after three years of Labor the unemployment statistics could be worse. We have had seven years of the accord. Here's another accord and the situation will be worse in three years time,' he said. So that was the formal view of the opposition at the time we made our commitment. That target has now been bettered, and in two years rather than three. . What are some of the key characteristics of the figures released today? As I said, total employment growth since April 1993 is now 560,000. Over the last month, 91,000 full time jobs were created. More Australians have a job today than ever before. In the last 12 months alone, 210,000 new full-time jobs have been created. That goes with a rising participation rate of 63.3 to 63.7 per cent. In my own state, the participation rate is now as high as 66.7 per cent. These are the statistics and the analysis that those opposite do not wish to discuss because they know it does them no good politically and they hate it. They hate to come into this place and talk about jobs. They hate to come into this place and talk about economic growth. They like to come into this place and sit there, as the Leader of the Opposition did, not rising to his feet, not saying a simple word-as he could have said last night on the Ray Martin show-yes or no to the key question. He did not say it last night; he did not say it today.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: It is none of your business. It's none of Ray Martin's business. Mr Lee--He said it's none of Ray Martin's business.

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: It is only Ray Martin's business because he is asking the questions. They are the questions that the Leader of the Opposition refuses to answer. In his contribution, I was very pleased to hear him make the point that the Leader of the Opposition only likes history when it refers to someone else. I like the history that refers to the Leader of the Opposition. Some of the economic history that refers to him is the following: when John Howard was Treasurer the average rate of economic growth was 2.1 per cent; the rate of inflation when John Howard left office was 11.4 per cent; the average rate of inflation under John Howard was 9.7 per cent; the average number of jobs created by John Howard per year was 52,000. Title: AND THE ARTS

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: AND THE ARTS

Title: AND THE ARTS

Title: AND THE ARTS

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: The Leader of the Opposition does not like history lessons that apply to him. As I have previously mentioned in the House-much to the dislike of the honourable member for O'Connorwhat is relevant to the past is often relevant to the future. I was very intrigued to see an extract from the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 September 1985. It was a most pertinent cartoon on John Howard. Little Johnny Howard is doing a doorstop and in the Petty cartoon he is quoted as saying, 'I would be less than loyal, honest, open and frank if I didn't admit my policies favour the rich, big, merciless and devious.' All Mr Howard had to do on the Ray Martin show last night was say yes or no. All he had to do in the House today was say yes or no. He failed or refused to do either. He is convicted by his own silence; he is convicted by the words from his own mouth on Ray Martin's show. I was also intrigued that at a time when the honourable member for Bennelong was making his silent and secret push to again become Leader of the Opposition there was an article in the Weekend Australian of 12-13 November under the heading 'New push for Howard falls short of a second coming'. It is by the Australian's national affairs editor Mike Steketee. It reads as follows: To adapt a comment made about one of the Liberals' election slogans: if the answer is John Howard, it must be a hell of a question. And so it is! Mr Steketee goes on to outline the attitude that a former colleague of Mr Howard had about the honourable member for Bennelong: The Liberal's, Peter Shack, the former .Liberal frontbencher, said of Howard "... he was hopeless in the shadow cabinet because, as chairman, he wanted to do most of the talking". We.: wish he would adopt the same approach in the House. We wish he would come into the House and say yes or no. We wish he would adopt the. same style that he. has in chairing shadow cabinet and come into the House or go onto the Ray Martin show and resolve this matter once and for all-yes or no. The reason he will not do it is that he has done a grubby deal. Mr Steketee concludes his article with the following: . . . a second Howard leadership simply would endorse the point made by the first: that he better out of the leadership that in it. He has been convicted by his own silence. He ought to come into this House and deny what he knows he cannot deny, because he knows, as a member of this House for over 20 years, that the one thing you cannot do in this House is mislead it. He knows that he cannot come into this House and deny that he has done a grubby secret deal which rides roughshod ()ver the media laws of this country and over decent policy so far as communications are concerned. Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: Farrer-Leader of the National Party of Australia) (5.28 p.m.}-For the benefit of honourable members, I am very happy to speak in support of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and reject the amending censure aspect from the government. In so doing, I indicate that I will do so for some five minutes, followed by one member from the government side, and then we will vote on this matter. Let it be a vote on conscience. On that basis honest John Howard would win because the government talks about evidence, but what evidence has it produced? We have had the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) relying on Ray Martin's transcript. We have had the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) relying on Ray Martin's transcript. We have had the Minister for Finance and Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) relying on Ray Martin's transcript. Every question the government would want to put up was there in Ray Martin's transcript. Ray Martin's transcript could have been written by a member of the government, but he is too professional for that. Who does Ray Martin work for? He works for Channel 9. Who owns Channel 9? Kerry Packer. The government wants us to believe that Kerry Packer has done a deal to give John Howard an easy time. What nonsense! What humbug! Indeed, so much humbug that it cannot even get its amendment right on the censure. In all my days as a member of this House I have never before seen the Leader of the House come in here with all his bravado, looks put down a huge draft amendment, which was then moved by the Minister for Communications and the Arts, and suddenly have the Speaker knock 30 per cent of the amendment out of order. Gone. Thirty per cent of the case mounted by the government has been literally torn up by none other than the Speaker. I am very pleased about that. The accusations are flying thick and fast. However, as the member for Flinders (Mr Reith) correctly pointed out, there is one central core issue. It is: where is the evidence? If there is no evidence, there is no deal. Where are the actual documents supporting the matter? Where are the telephone transcripts? Where are the statutory declarations? If this case was worth one iota of serious consideration, surely, they would have been able to produce one statutory declaration from someone in the Packer camp. But they have been unable to do so. It is hard to believe that, because they have been unable to do so, they have actually defamed their former senatorial colleague Graham Richardson, they have actually defamed the former Labor Hawke operator Peter Barron and, in a sense, they have  I have no particular desire to support or defend any particular media owner or operator in this country. I have met most of them over the years and they are big enough to defend themselves. The truth is, and we come right back to the nub point, that if there is no evidence, there is no deal. That is where this case rests at the end of this parliamentary sitting week, with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gone mad in Germany, Singapore and in just about every other port-he even managed to get excited at a refuelling stop in Dubai-and a government unable to back up the case and the Minister for Communications and the Arts taking the wrong line in the process. There is one other question I, being a person of fair and good humour, thought could have been asked of the Minister for Communications and the Arts today in all the circumstances. Given the minister's detailed knowledge of conspiracy theories, including the so-.called secret deal between Mr .Kerry Packer and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), can the minister also reveal Harold Holt's current Chinese address? Can he also reveal who killed President Kennedy? And, for the sake of Triple J, can the minister us where Elvis Presley is currently located? That is how extraordinary your conspiracy theories are. They are a load of nonsense. We know they are a load of nonsense and the people of Australia know they are a load of nonsense. In the last 18 hours I have been to two big functions in Sydney. This morning I went to Cobar for an important local government conference, to Bourke for a land protection board conference and

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: What are the Aboriginal people saying about the member for Barker?

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: I will tell you what the people are saying out there. They are saying: if there was any deal, why would the government not have produced any evidence--one bit of paper or one statutory declaration-to back up the matter? The truth is: no evidence; no deal. On that score, this minister stands absolutely condemned for his total failure to produce one shred of evidence to back up his inSUlting accusations of an honest Leader of the Opposition, honest John Howard.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: This debate today, and statements from members of the opposition over the past four months, prove that they will say anything, do anything, think anything and do any deal to slime their way back into power. There is no doubt that this has been a Goebbels type campaign by the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), and members of the front bench over there to turn themselves from hard Right ideologues into soft, furry, fuzzy, kind social democrats. But nobody believes you. You came into this House today and asked, 'Where's your evidence?' We are guilty because we do not have the evidence that you have done a deal with Kerry Packer! What sort of logic is that? You have done the deal. On the Ray Martin show last night your leader, the member for Bennelong, said that he was prepared to change the cross-media ownership rules. That is the evidence. Let us look at the deals you have done in recent times. Let us look at the backflips that have taken place in recent times. It took the memtell ber for Bennelong seven years to apologise for his remarks on Asian immigration. Who can believe him? It is not what you say; it is what you think. The next election is going to be some sort of mind-reading exercise when it comes to the opposition. No-one is going to believe what you say about Asian immigration. No-one is going to believe what you say about public spending. Nobody is going to believe what you say about the social security safety net. Nobody is going to believe what you say about industrial relations. They all know that Fightback is what you believe in-it is your bible. Every time we ask you what your current policy is you say, 'Fightback doesn't count any more, but we're not going to tell you what our policy is now.' The Leader of the Opposition said to Ray Martin last night, 'Ray, I'm not going to tell you. Let's not get into personalities.' I agree. Let us not get into personalities, let us get into a debate about the cross-media ownership rules and where the Liberal Party stands. It is very clear where you stand: you are going to water them down. It is very clear where you stand. You have  to junk the cross-media ownership rules, and you are going to do or say anything in a very grubby attempt to win votes at the next election. It will not work. You are not going to skate through the next election campaign pretending that you do not have any policies because we will take it up with you time and time again. The member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) is over there. Today he said that the employment figures were disappointing. He thinks that having created 560,000 jobs in the past two years is disappointing. Dr Kemp-I didn't say that.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: Order! The honourable member for Goldstein, don't be provoked. There is a form of the House that you can use later.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: Why don't you come clean and admit that you don't care about the unemployed? You have no programs whatsoever. We have a program, and it is called Working Nation. Today there are 560,000 Australians working because of Working Nation. It is putting wealth back into the community and giving people a future. Mr Forrest- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I do not know whether you are listening very carefully to the member, to the things he is actually accusing you of in his continual reference to 'you'. I think you should ask him to address his remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: I am very appreciative of the honourable member for Mallee for bringing that to my attention. I remind all members of this place to speak through the chair.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: AND THE ARTS
text: We know that those on the other side are experts at deal making. We know so from the Financial Review. We know how the former Leader of the Opposition, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), went down. There was a meeting at the Chateau Hotel in December. Who was there? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) and the puppeteer of the Liberal Party, the person who pulls the strings on the opposition front bench, Mr Ron Walker, the person who funds the Liberal Party, the person who pays the piper, the person who gives $30 million a year to the Liberal Party, the person who is probably setting up offshore funding for the Liberal Party in South Australia and the person who is behind your attempts to avoid the disclosure legislation. Those opposite are experts at dirty deals behind the scenes. You know all about it. Members of the opposition are experts at doing deals. You were experts at doing deals when you junked the then Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, and when you junked the previous Leader of the Opposition. You know all about it. You will do anything, which is why you are prepared to engage in  why you will not come clean and admit that you have made that private commitment to junk the cross-media ownership rules. It is absolutely incredible that the only charge you make against this side of the House is that we do not have any evidence. We have the evidence of your policy. Otherwise, those opposite would come forward and admit that they support the current crossmedia ownership rules. Your failure to do so condemns you as deal makers extraordinaire. You will do anything and say anything in a sleazy attempt to mislead the Australian electorate. I can assure you that you will not get there. Main Committee adjourned at 11.59 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: Noise Levels: Melbourne Airport (Question No. 1698) Mr Atkinson asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 November 1994: (1) How many (a) private homes, (b) schools and colleges, (c) hospitals, (d) health care facilities and (e) child care facilities are estimated to lie within an area adjacent to (i) Tullamarine, (ii) Essendon and (iii) Moorabbin airports that are presently subject to Australian Noise Exposure Index contours of (A) 20 to 25, (B) 25 to 30, (C) 30 to 35 and (D) 35 plus. (2) What studies has his Department or other agencies such as the Federal Airports Corporation conducted since 1989 into noise levels at each airport referred to in part (1).

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: REPRESENTATIVES MAIN COMMITTEE
text: The amended answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) I am advised that noise contours for movements at Melbourne Airport during 1988 (1988 ANEI) identified that: (a) in the 20-25 zone there were 5,882 dwellings, 11 schools and colleges, no hospitals, 2 health care facilities and 5 child care facilities; (b) in the 25-30 zone there were 1,775 dwellings, 3 schools and colleges and 3 child care facilities; (c) in the 30-35 zone there were 21 dwellings; and (d) in the 35+ zone there was one dwelling. In respect of Essendon Airport, I am advised that an ANEI based on 1984/85 traffic indicated that at the time 670 dwellings were within the 25+ ANEI zone. I am advised that information is not available in respect of the number of schools, colleges, hospitals, health care or child care facilities falling within the ANEF zones at Essendon Airport. Location State No. of Properties Braddon ACT 1 (Fenner Hall), (formerly Gowrie Aust. Belmont NSW 3 Booragul NSW 1 Cessnock NSW 12 NA At Moorabbin Airport the 1990 ANEI indicated that there were 250 dwellings in the 20-25 ANEI zone and 50 within the 25-30 ANEI zone. Since then traffic levels have declined which would mean that currently there may be fewer dwellings in these zones. I am advised that no hospitals, schools, health care or child care facilities exist within the ANEF zones, although a secondary college and one hospital lie on the 20 ANEI contour at Moorabbin Airport. (2) In 1993/94 a noise and flight path monitoring system was installed at Melbourne Airport. This system provides noise level and flight path information relating to aircraft movements at Melbourne and Essendon Airports. The most recent noise monitoring study for Moorabbin Airport was conducted in 1989.
