(2) Is he able to indicate the size of the potential SBS viewing population in the regions and the estimated cost of extending SBS transmission to the regions. (3) Which regions of Australia do not receive SBS television or have not been allocated funding for its transmission. (4) Is he able to indicate the size of the potential SBS viewing population in each region referred to in part (3) and the estimated cost of extending SBS transmission to each region. Mr Lee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The issue of extensions of the SBS transmissions will be considered in the context of future budgets with the views and needs of residents of the Albury-Wodonga, Southern Riverina and NorthEast Victoria regions, and the claims of other areas in Australia, being taken into account. (2) Albury/Wodonga, the Southern Riverina and North-East Victoria are within the Upper Murray coverage area served by the transmission facility at Mt Baranduda. On the basis of the 1991 Census, the population of the potential SBS viewing population within the Upper Murray coverage area is approximately 154,000. An indicative estimate of the cost of providing such a service is $2.2m capital and $0.3m per annum for operation and maintenance. (3) Over 75% of Australians are able to receive SBS television via Government provided terrestrial facilities. The areas which are covered are listed below: disposal of the property by AEM range of sporting facilities in the States in the sports the AIS pays for the use of facilities at the office space for coaches anq administrative staff. of office space in Sydney (55m2) and Brisbane owned by the Bureau of Meteorology or staff Institute of the Supervising Scientist. Canberra Newcastle Sydney Wollongong Darwin Brisbane Gold Coast Cairns Darling Downs Townsville Adelaide Spencer Gulf North Hobart North East Tasmania Ballarat Bendigo Latrobe Valley Melbourne Perth In addition, the Wide Bay and Richmond/Tweed areas are scheduled to receive the service in 1995/96. Some communities outside the above areas have set up their own facilities to access SBS television via satellite. (4) Issues such as population size and coverage are re-examined prior to each Budget. The population of coverage areas can vary over time quite significantly. Costs vary considerably depending on topography, geographic size of the area to be covered, signal strength required and infrastructure costs to accommodate the new facilities. Indicative costs are the estimates for extending the service to RichmondlTweed of $1.82m for capital and $0.29m for operation and maintenance and Wide Bay of $3.03m for capital and $0.60m for operation and maintenance. Papua New Guinea: Aid (Question No. 1943)

Speaker: Mr CAMERON
Title: AUSTRADE
text: the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 2 February 1995: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1808 (Hansard,31 January 1995, page 147), does the Government's refusal to investigate claims concerning the moving of funds from Papua New Guinea before the kina was floated indicate a willingness to ignore how Australian aid to other countries is used. (2) Does the Government require countries to whom aid is given to account for its use; if not, why not; if so, how is the accountability specified. (3) Will he provide evidence of how all monetary assistance provided by Australia to Papua New Guinea has been spent; if not, why not. (4) Will he ensure that all aid given to all countries in future is fully accounted for. Mr Bilney-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) No. It simply reflects the fact that, in this situation, and as indicated in my reply to Question 1808 of 5 December 1994, the investigation of such claims or allegations is a matter for the appropriate Papua New Guinea (pNG) authorities. Should those authorities approach the Australian Government, the Government would cooperate with any duly authorised investigation. (2) Most of Australia's aid is provided in the form of Australian goods and services for specific, rigorously designed projects and programs. In this way, the aid we provide can be managed and monitored from port of dispatch to project site. We aim for stringent accountability in all our arrangements with contractors, consultants, international organisations and other governments. Further, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), undertakes its own regular and intensive monitoring and evaluation of aid projects and programs through its network of aid posts in developing countries and Canberra-based personnel. These procedures, combined with effective monitoring and review mechanisms, make it extremely difficult for aid funds to be redirected to alternative uses by recipient countries and ensure that the aid program is well directed. PNG is the only country to which we provide significant assistance in monetary form as untied budget support. However, both the Australian and PNG Governments have agreed that budget support will be phased out by the end of the decade. It is planned that there will be, commencing in FY 1994/95, a seven year straight line reduction of budget support to zero in FY 2000/01, and a corresponding increase in sector program aid. This will be consistent with the approach we take with other countries receiving Australian aid. (3) Yes. In FY 1994/5 $213.4 million will be provided in the form of budget support, $77.3 million will be provided in the form of jointly programmed aid and $16 million will be provided in the form of retirement benefits and termination payments to officers of pre Independence administrations. Budget support payments are paid directly to the PNG Government and are disbursed as part of the annual budget appropriations made by the PNG Parliament. As such, these funds are disbursed through the normal processes of the PNG Government as reflected in the annual national budget. Program aid is provided to support a wide range of development activities in six priority sectors (infrastructure, health, education, law and order, renewable resources and the private sector). The sector programs include provision of technical assistance, accountable grants for infrastructure, grants to community groups, scholarships, equipment and supplies to support sector programs and projects. Funds disbursed through program activities are expended in line with Commonwealth financial regulations for expenditure of public monies. As well as the above, minor aid flows to PNG are also provided through a range of other program mechanisms. These include Development Training courses, Regional and Multi Country Programs, Emergency and Humanitarian Relief, support for Non-Government Organisation, Direct Aid Program projects through the Head of Mission Discretionary Aid Fund and Australian Development Cooperation Scholarships. In FY 1993/4 monetary assistance through these channels totalled approximately $22.75 million. As with program aid, accountability for expenditure is in accord with Commonwealth procedures. I refer Mr Cameron to the AIDAB statistical manual Australian Overseas Development Cooperation 1989/90 to 1993/94: Official Expenditure by country, Region and Sector for detailed descriptions of monetary assistance to PNG over the past five years and to Budget Related Paper No.2, Australia's Development Cooperation Program 1994-5 for estimates of FY 1994/5 assistance. (4) As described in the answer provided for question 2, Australia's aid program has effective mechanisms in place to ensure that official development assistance reaches intended recipients, is used efficiently, and is directed at meeting development and humanitarian concerns. Government Schools: Recurrent Costs (Question No. 1948) Mr Andrews asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice,on 2 February 1995: (1) Has he or the Department of Employment, Education and Training considered the report of the consultancy to investigate elements of government school recurrent costs dated 8 February 1994. (2) Did the report conclude that, for the average government school recurrent cost to be a materially accurate reflection of the average costs of educating a student in a government school, issues relating to superannuation, inconsistencies between accounting practices, privately raised funds and accrual accounting need to be addressed; if so, does he endorse the conclusion. Mr Free-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) The report reached those conclusions. As implementation of the recommendations would be dependent on the States and Territories agreeing to change some elements of the National Schools Statistics Collection, I am not in a position to endorse the report's conclusion. The report was provided to the Taskforce on School Statistics of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs for its consideration. The varying accounting and reporting procedures in the States and Territories mean that implementation of some recommendations, if accepted, may take some years. SES Vacancies (Question No. 1977) Mr Campbell asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 7 February 1995: (1) Were the prescribed procedures for filling SES vacancies followed in the appointment of Mr Phillip Toyne to a position in the Minister's Department. (2) Was the position advertised in newspapers; if so, (a) in which newspapers and (b) over what period. (3) Was Mr Toyne interviewed for selection; if so, who were the members of the interviewing panel. (4) Did the (a) Minister or (b) Secretary of the Department confirm the appointment; if not, who did. (5) If the Minister confirmed the appointment, is it usual practice for ministerial involvement in this type of activity. (6) How many applications were received for the position. (7) How did the successful applicant distinguish himself in the selection process from the unsuccessful applicants. (8) Do nOl,1llal Australian Public Service (APS) conditions apply to the appointment of Mr Toyne. (9) Is the appointment (a) permanent or (b) under contract. (10) If the appointment is under contract, do any special provisions apply to the appointment in addition to normal APS conditions; if so, what are they.

text: The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) Yes. (2) Yes. (10) No. (Question No. 2039) Dr Kemp asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 8 February 1995: (1) According to the most recent data, what percentage of persons who participated in the Jobstart program are in unsubsidised employment at the conclusion of their participation in the program. (2) Does the data referred to in part (1) cover only the three months immediately after the conclusion of the Jobstart subsidies. (3) What is known about the proportion of Jobstart participants who are in unsubsidised employment more than three months after the termination of subsidies and after payment of any relevant bonus. Mr Crean-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The most recent available data are for the months ending December 1994. These data show that some 59% offormer Jobstartparticipantswere in unsubsidised employment around 3 months after participation in the program. Jobstart (2) Yes. (3) There is evidence that J obstart outcomes are, in general, sustained over the longer term. Information on the longer term outcomes of former participants was gathered between March and September 1992 as part of the evaluation of Jobstart. The evaluation found that around 53% of former participants were in employment 6 to 8 months after termination of subsidy payments. This outcomes level is comparable to the post program monitoring estimate for the year to end March 1992 which indicated that 55% of clients were in employment 3 months after program participation. Further information on longer term Jobstart outcomes was gathered between August 1994 and January 1995 as part of the development of extended post program monitoring. Estimates based on pilot surveys indicate that longer term outcomes levels are comparable to those at 3 months after program participation. While the data are subject to seasonal influences and require confirmation through further surveys, unsubsidised employment 12 outcomes 6 and 12 months after program participation were found to be around 60%. Reliable data on unsubsidisedemployment levels following payment of bonuses to employers will not become available until 1997.
